text:
A good basic cookie, a little heavy on the salt. If your cookies come out  flat it is most likely due to over mixing. Cream butter and sugar until very light and fluffy 4 or 5 mins. if  you like. Add the dry ingredients and mix by hand just 'till blended.  Your cookies will always stay nice and full.  Over baking can also cause your cookies to flatten out.  Cookies will continue to bake after taken from the oven so don't over do it.

text:
This is a really good cookie. Would have given it 5 stars, but did need to increase the flour to 1 3/4 cup and baking soda to 1 teaspoon. If you use margarine or salted butter, DEcrease the salt to 1/4 tsp or just omit altogether. Salt that is suggested in cookie recipes are generally listed for bakers who use UNsalted butter. This made 36 good sized cookies. I chilled the dough for around 30 minutes, due to reading o thers having spreading problems. I made them a tad larger than a 'normal' sized cookie. I did an experiment and baked these (with above changes) at 350 for 12 minutes, they spread too much, became too brown around the edges and were only chewy in the dead center. Next batch I baked at 350 for 10 minutes, then 11, and finally to 12...because anything under 12 the center was still quite doughy but at 12 they spread quite a bit and were more thin and crispy than soft or chewy. At 325, 12 minutes cookies were too raw and any longer and the center would get overbaked. I then set the oven up to 335, yes 335, and baked for 12 minutes. PERFECTO. Results were: the cookie was softer, only very edges were crisp, center was soft and still slightly puffy. My suggestions would be to add about 1/2 cup more flour, and the full tsp of baking soda (you can not taste it and it does not produce a cake like cookie by any means), if you're kitchen is warm- chill the dough for 30 minutes to an hour and bake for the 12 minutes at 335. This is my new oatmeal cookie. Thanks Dr Amy!!

text:
Can't give this recipe 5 stars because it took several changes to get the AMAZING cookies that were the final result. My husband is a "cookie monster" & said these very well may be the best cookies ever. Here's what I changed: 1) Added 1/2 extra cup flour (for a grand total of 1 and 3/4 cup flour). 2) Cut the salt down to less than 1/2 teaspoon 3)I increased the baking soda by half a teaspoon for a grand total of one FULL teaspoon baking soda 4)Used about 3/4 cup Cape Cod dried cranberries and half a bag of Hershey's milk chocolate chips. 5)I whipped the butter and sugar until VERY light and fluffy. 6) After mixing the rest of the batter I stuck the bowl of batter into the freezer for about ten minutes before baking. I used a cookie dough scoop to make rounded ice cream scoop shapes of dough on the cookie sheet (which I lined with a Silpat baking sheet). 7) I cooked them at 335 until they still looked like they needed another minute or two -- looked a little wet still and when tapped with a finger on top they "deflated" a little. 8) I took them out of the oven and left them on the cookie sheet for about two to five minutes before transferring to a cooling rack. Note: I put the dough into the fridge between batches so it stayed firm. No spreading took place during baking. The day after baking these they remain super chewy and moist. PERFECTION. Good enough to give with Christmas cookie assortment. UPDATE: Add cinnamon!

text:
Oh my, oh my - these are TO die for! Now that I've made them several times, here's how they turn out the best:
* set butter and eggs out so they are room temp. before using
* make sure you mix the 2nd set of ingredients seperate from the sugar/butter mixture
* add a 1/2 cup more flour
* add a dash of cinnamon
* cut the vanilla to 1 tsp.
* cut the salt to 1/2 tsp 
* use the highest quality chocolate chips
* once ingredients are all together, stir JUST until mixed
* drop into taller piles on cookie sheet
Woah . Yum!

text:
Read the modifications & made these - THEY CAME OUT PERFECT!!!  1) Cookies can be runny when you use ALL butter (it has such a low melting point) so I used 1/2 butter and 1/2 crisco (i used plain - but butter crisco works too) 2) do not use an electric mixer!!!! it breaks everything down WAY TOO MUCH.... just use a wooden or large metal spoon to mix... and mix it JUST enough.... gentle! 3) after the wet ingredients ... PUT IN THE OATMEAL (i used 1/2 quick oats and 1/2 real oats because the quick oats break down). still, the oats stirred into the wet ingredients sop up any moisture 4) used pecan instead of walnuts - they aren't bitter. put them in next before the flour also so they get mixed in well with the batter. IF YOU DO NOT USE NUTS - ADD 1/4 c. MORE FLOUR!! 5) then put in the flour and soda/salt - I use the same proportion of salt and soda and they come out great - 1/2 t. each 6) chocolate chips last - 1 c. is a good amount and mix barely until mixed.  SECRET FOR BAKING: if you bake them immediately, then 335 for 12 minutes.  If you put them in the frig - 350 for 13 minutes. 7) LAST BIG SECRET:  The recipe calls for letting them rest on the hot baking sheet for 5 minutes - DO THAT!!! IT IS REALLY IMPORTANT!!!  Yummmmmm!

text:
I've been making these cookies for years, and for some reason never rated them.  These are PHENOMENAL.  Probably the best homemade cookies I've ever made.  I follow the recipe exactly with the exception of adding the walnuts.  My only suggestion is, if you are using salted butter, be sure to omit the extra salt.  It's not necessary to use salt at all in that case, and in fact, they'll turn out to be too salty if you do.  Also, if you really want them to be chewy and soft, be sure to take them out while they still look slightly undercooked. Cookies that are golden brown always become hard after they cool down.  If you're like me and you only like soft cookies, take them out while they're still a little bit gooey.  Once they cool off, they'll firm up a bit, but still be soft.

text:
I thought these were great.  And unlike others, I really didn't think it needed any modifications.  It really DID seem like the dough/batter was just "wrong", it looked wrong, felt wrong, and seemed like it would never become a cookie, because it was just a blob of oatmeal coated in stuff and didn't have much cohesion at all.  I DID have a huge urge to modify it (and adding more flour was my top compulsion), but I resisted.  Once baked they were perfect. I think the key is to get them out at the right time.  12 minutes in my oven (notoriously under-powered) was quite undercooked, so I had to go 13-14 minutes to have them turn out right.  Just know your oven, and adjust accordingly, that's my best advice.  At least make them un-tweaked once so you know what you're changing.  IF I were going to change anything next time it would probably be a little less sugar and (gasp) I'd omit the chocolate chips.  I just loved the nutty earthy oatmeal of this cookie and wanted less distraction from it.  Great recipe, thanks for sharing.  Edited to add: This works absolutely fine with old fashioned oats.  We don't use quick oats in my family, so that's all we had, and all we wanted, and it turned out perfect, fine and yummy.

text:
This was my first cookie recipe as an adult (ha!) I'm getting rave reviews on these and my sister even told me I could enter these in a contest. First try I omitted the walnuts and I added an extra cup of chocolate chips & a few heaping teaspoons of unsweetened cocoa powder. I used big mounds of dough on the 12x17 ungreased sheet (12 cookies on the sheet @ a time).I made these again yesterday, this time making the mounds smaller on the sheet (20 cookies @ a time).Used the recipe as is, then split the dough in half: in one I used a cup of walnuts & a cup of chocolate chips: they came out SO GOOD. In the other I used a cup of Reece's Pieces for hubby & he said (with a mouthful of cookie) "mmph...good job hon!"

My cookies ended up baking for about 17 minutes @ 325. Cooled on the pan for a couple minutes. The bigger cookies needed a full 5, the smaller ones could be taken off almost immediately.
No problems with runny dough, but the reece's pieces cookies looked flatter like they WANTED to run, but didnt.
When mixing the dough, I first creamed the butter and sugars etc & put all the dry ingredients into a re-sealable baggy. I ground up 2.5 cups of the rolled oats and left the other 1/2 whole & added that to the dry ingredients in the baggy too, shook it all up, THEN added the dry ingredients to the wet ones. Mixed only until incorporated.
The dough stayed in the frige in between batches.
I will DEFINATELY make these again!

text:
This is very good base recipe.  For those complaining it's too salty-try 1/2 tsp salt instead of 1 tsp salt.  I follow this general rule with cookies: anytime a recipe calls for 1/2 tsp of baking soda or baking powder, that's the same amount of salt I add.  Also, it does start out slightly runny, but just space your dough drops to give room for baking -once they bake they will be perfect.  I always pull my cookies out about 30 sec-1min before they are actually done, and then let them cool a few min before moving them and they are always perfect.  I suggest adding about 1/2 cup more choc chips and also 1/2 tsp cinnamon and a dash or two of nutmeg for a little kick.  Another killer thing to add is some shredded coconut for a change up.  For butter- I use just plain old country crock and it's delicious everytime. Another thing you can do is substitute baking powder for the soda and it will bake your cookies up a little more.  And if this has too much oats for you-try 2 1/2 cups instead of 3 and just add a touch more flour.  Another great change up-try half butterscotch or peanut butter chips and half choc chips.
     that's all my tips for this rockin recipe!

text:
Delicious cookie, but BEWARE. Recipe doesn't say, but you need heaping TABLESPOONS to form, not teaspoons. That's why one reader said it made an enormous amount. Also, you need to bake longer, or at higher temperature. Cookies are not done 12 minutes at 325 degrees. Don't let this stop you. Cookies have fabulous flavor. I did not have quick-cooking oats, so I processed regular oats for 10 seconds in food processor. It also might be a good idea to chill dough for about 10 minutes in fridge before or after molding in order to avoid undue spreading when baking. And cool on sheet a full five minutes before removing cookies to rack. Sounds like lots of work, but really are fairly easy to make. And definitely worth it -- wonderful texture and flavor.

I followed other reviewers suggestions and increased the flour to 1 3/4 cup and the baking soda to 1 tsp. With those changes, this is a 5 star recipe, but as written, only about a 4. Everyone LOVED these cookies. I used about 2 cups old-fashioned oats and 1 cup of quick-cooking oats as I didn't have enough quick-cooking oats. I've never had Beatrice'e Excellent Oatmeal cookies, but these reminded me of Great Harvest Bread Company's Oatmeal cookies which are absolutely fabulous (though their cookies do not have chocolate chips). Oh, and based upon personal preference, I did not add the walnuts. This recipe (with the changes) is a keeper!

GO, MAKE THESE RIGHT NOW! This was my first time making any type of oatmeal cookies from scratch. I followed the directions, but made a half batch and altered the recipe based on reviews to 3/4 cup flour, 1/2 tsp baking soda, and 1/4 tsp salt (next time I will make the full batch with 1 1/2 cups flour, 1 tsp baking soda, and 1/2 tsp salt). I baked for 14 minutes at 325, let sit on the cookie sheet for 5, and then as soon as they were off the sheets, they magically disappeared! Everyone in my family LOVES these! Maybe it's a good thing I didn't make the full batch, or I would still be eating them :) OH ALSO, IF YOU ONLY HAVE TRADITIONAL NON-QUICK OATS, put them in a food processer for a few seconds and voila, instant oats!

I am adding to my original review below...
I have made these for months now as stated on the recipe with no spreading...until last week...because I over softened the butter and did not chill for five minutes the cookie dough.  For low carb version see below and sub oat flour and whole wheat flour for white flour. 
Original post
This is always something that has confused me, how can you rate a recipe when you didn't make it as it was listed?  I made this exactly like the recipe called for and they were great, friends and family loved them!  I also made them as a low carb offering using half whole wheat flour half white flour, splenda brown sugar and An all natural agave based no cal sweetner for the sugar.  Truvia or one of the others.   They are obviously different but family and friends thought they were great and the trade off was not that much.  I always put cookie dough on the sheet and then in fridge (5 min)  to set up to help with spreading I will now try all the other suggestions...but this recipe as is is my rating!

text:
an excellent oatmeal cookie recipe!  one tip that i have found to be true after having more batches of cookies than i care to admit to having "spread" or get very flat and crispy:  when it says to use "softened butter," make sure it really is softened.  i take two sticks of butter from the refrigerator and microwave them for 30 seconds.. this way they are *just starting* to melt.  and then there are no problems with the cookies spreading.  if your butter is too cold, it melts when you bake the cookie, thus you have cookies that "spread," or come out flat and crispy.
note:  the only change i had to make is to bake at 350° instead of 325°.

I have been making cookie for fifteen years and I have become very selective about which recipes I use and prefer to just wing it and create my own, however, last year I got married and recived the allrecipes cookbook for a gift and I made this cookies and my husband melted. He prefers them with butterscotch chips and no walnuts which translates roughly to 12oz of chips in stead of 8 to make up the bulk. He, and now all of his friends, love love love these cookies, I highly reccomend them. My only caution is that if you are like me and like to tweak recipes and bake times, don't. The "chewy" of these cookies is a result of the low oven temp and the sitting on the pan for the 5 extra minutes. Enjoy!!!

text:
Best oatmeal cookie I've ever made. I followed the recipe exactly but did have to use pecans instead of walnuts because that's what I had. I used mini-chocolate chips too. My recommendations are to follow the recipe exactly; do not cut the salt since the salt/sweet contrast is what makes them good. Also use real butter and use a nonstick pan or wax paper but don't spray extra grease on. They're the best and I bake a lot of cookies. They also have a tollhouse flavor to them.

text:
I love oatmeal cookies with chocolate chips and this recipe fits the bill.  I'm a Dietitian so I modified this recipe to make it a bit healthier without losing the yummy goodness.  I cut the butter by 1/4 C and used applesauce in it's place.  Also, I used only 3/4 C brown sugar and 1/3 white sugar.  I left out the salt like others recommended with the buttered salt and I used 3/4 C all purpose flour and 1/2C whole wheat flour in place of the full amount of flour.  I didn't change the eggs, but you can use 2 egg whites in place of 1 whole egg to cut some of the fat/cholesterol.
Anyhow, long story short....MY FAMILY LOVED THESE COOKIES and this recipe is a keeper even with the substitutions.

text:
I've made these cookies at least 20 times since I found this recipe last summer. Absolutely great! Everyone who has had them have said that they are the best chocolate chip oatmeal cookies they've EVER had!

Just a few suggestions: Half the amount of salt. I'm not saying this as a matter of preference. 1 teaspoon is too much and ends up making them taste like salted cookies. 
The best kind of butter to use is unsalted sweet cream butter. Never make the mistake of substituting margarine for the butter or they will turn out very oily. 

Also, depending on how powerful your oven is, the baking time is between 10 - 12 minutes at 325 degrees -- no more, no less! If you let them stay for a minute over 12, they will not be as chewy.

text:
These cookies were good. I used butter flavored shortening for half of the butter, used regular oats and switched the amounts of baking soda (1 tsp) and salt (1/2 tsp). (Even with cutting the salt, I could still taste it so I'll probably use 1/4 tsp next time!) In half of the batter, I added a big spoonful of (about 1/4 cup) peanut butter. I didn't have any problem with spreading, but maybe that's because I used regular oats and the batter was thicker? I only baked for 10 minutes; enough time to get browned around the edges but still a little gooey in the middle. Then I let them cool for 2 minutes on the sheet before removing to a rack. Both batches of cookies turned out well - nice and chewy - and I thought the addition of nuts gave it that little extra "something". Will make these again!

Mmmkay, you don't need to add more ingredients and you don't have to freeze the dough for two hours. I would suggest putting in 1/4-1/2 cup more oats. (Yummy!)

Obviously you have to take in the climate and humidity, so perhaps the woman who added more flour lives in a humid climate and the one who suggested freezing it for two hours lives in an overly hot climate. If either of those apply to you, please do use thier suggestions!

With that said, if you just use an ice cream scooper to scoop your dough onto the sheet, it might help with the shaping. Also, if you worry about speading, just 10 to 15 minutes in the freezer does it just fine. 

Hope this helps!

I made these last night and I'm still eating them! I did do what other reviewers said and only added 1/2 tsp.salt. I also added 1/2 tsp. cinnamon (I love Mexican chocolate)and a whole bag (2 cups?)of semi sweet choc. chips instead of the 1 cup that is called for. Yummy- perfect with a cup of milk. With these around I get my whole days calcium b/c I'm always eating them and drinking milk!!!

UPDATE 12/2006: I just made 2 batches of this to give away for xmas treats. I forgot I made these last year and put in the 1 tspn.of salt. My first batch was made with Guittard semi-sweet chips (I guess a good brand made with real vanilla and chocolate). I baked these at 12 minutes and they came out GREAT. My second batch I used a generic brand chip (made with artificial vanilla!) and overcooked the cookies in my first pan by 3 minutes. HORRIBLE!!! They were way too salty. Now I know why some reviews said this cookie is salty- don't overcook it AND use a good chip. Even without overcooking, my second batch made with the generic choc. chips weren't as good as my first batch and too salty for my taste. What a waste b/c now I can't wrap these up as presents! It pays to get good ingredients!

text:
Wow, what a fantastic cookie!  I followed what other reviewers suggested and added a 1/2 cup of flour and an extra 1/2 tsp of baking soda.  Before I add the dry ingredients to the wet, I always whisk or sift them together.  I also made sure to stir until combined and no more.  They were all baked at the recommended temperature for 12 minutes, no more no less, and cooled for 5 minutes on the pan (don't worry if they look too soft, they'll get more chewy while cooling on the pan).  The first batch were a bit flat, though the subsquent batches that had a chance to cool in the fridge kept their rounded shape a bit better - both looked and tasted great either way, so don't necessarily worry about chilling your dough.  The cookies were slightly brown on the bottom and soft in the middle with a perfect chewy factor.  Awesome recipe.

text:
Very good cookie , but needed some tweaks as other reviewers have mentioned. I used 1 c unsalted butter so I did need to use 1/2 tsp salt, increased baking soda to 1 tsp, increased flour to 1 3/4 c whole wheat flour.  I creamed butter and sugar until good and fluffy then added eggs and vanilla, then flour, salt, and baking soda. Oats 3 c, walnuts 1 c and chocolate chips 3/4 c, can be folded in or mixed on low briefly.  I also added 3/4 c craisins because my family loves them.  I refrigerated  the dough for 30 min and baked at 335 for 12 min. This produced a nice lofty soft cookie.  I have made the above revised version of this recipe many times with great success. The only problem is that the cookies disappear too quick. :-)

text:
I followed the suggestions of others and increased the flour, soda, and oats by 1/2 cup. I also only used 1/4 t salt since I always use margarine.  Two reasons I noticed for the cookie spreading too much in my first batch was not letting it chill long enough and not enough oats. A trick I learned several years ago is to only bake one sheet at a time and once you transfer the cookies put the sheet in the freezer for a minute. This will keep the dough from spreading before it gets in the oven. The taste and texture is perfect!

This is the cookie recipe I've been looking for my whole life!  I've made this recipe three times now.  The first two times the cookies came out soft and chewy and very tasty.  I did take the advice of some reviews and added a 1/2 cup more flour, doubled the baking soda, and decreased the salt by half.  I also placed the batter in the fridge for 30 mins before baking to decrease spreading/flat cookies.  The 3rd time I followed the recipe exactly without the modification and the result...disappointment.  The cookies spread (even though I placed the batter in the fridge for 1/2 hr).  They weren't the same cookies...they weren't as good.  As a result, I will continue to bake them with the modifications.  Follow the modifications and these are Wonderful cookies!  Everyone who tried them thought so too and consequently they disappeared in no time, and left friends asking when I plan on making more :)

I tried baking a batch after refrigerating the dough for about an hour vs. a batch of room temperature dough. I must say the refrigerated dough held its shape better and didn't turn out as flat as the room temp. version. I also increased the bake time to 14 min. at 325 deg which resulted in good edges but still chewy centers. This was a hit with my kids and their friends so this is a keeper for me! Thank you!

text:
These are my new favorite cookies!  Thanks so much for the recipe.    Here are the modifications I made:  * eliminate salt if using salted butter  * use 1.5 cups flour  * use 1 tsp baking soda  * They come out nice and chewy with 2 cups oats; they are crunchier with 3 cups oats  * I used 2 cups of chocolate instead of one (1 cup milk chocolate chips, 1/2 cup dark chocolate chips, 1/2 cup Heath bar chips)  * I roll them into balls and/or chill them for 2 hours before baking to prevent spreading.  Best cookies ever!  -- Laura

I have been making this recipe for years now, and it is a favorite.  It is the only chocolate chip cookie recipe I use.  The only changes I have made are to use half butter and half butter flavored shortening.  In my humid climate, it seems to make the cookies hold up a little better. I play with this recipe all of the time - sometimes using half white flour and half wheat, sometimes substituting white chocolate chips and Craisins for the chocolate chips.  I have added coconut and macadamia nuts, and even chopped up extra dark chocolate and added it (that was a favorite!). Truly - there is no way to go wrong with this recipe!!

text:
Finally a basic Oatmeal cookie recipe that turns out chewy & moist and not flat. I followed the tips on refrigerating the dough for a couple of hours before baking. Instead of 1 1/4 cup of white flour I used 1/2 cup whole wheat, 1/2 cup white and 1/4 cup of oat flour. I also added 2 tbsp of flax seed flour, an extra 1/4 of oats and omitted the nuts adding raisins instead. Mixed with my kitchen aid mixer and scooped with a cookie dough scooper. It made perfect little cookies that didn't spread. Thanks so much for my new standard Oatmeal cookie. Oh...i also deleted all nuts, used 1/2 cup choc chips and 1/2 cup of raisins. I also strongly recommend only half the salt.

text:
I followed this recipe exactly, only omitting the walnuts, and the cookies were still soft and chewy the next day! For those who don't have the same good luck, try my grandmother's trick. Store "hard" cookies in a sealed container, along with a piece of fresh bread, several hours or overnight. When you remove the bread, the cookies will have absorbed its moisture and be soft again. Voila!

text:
I love my old Oatmeal Chocolate Chip cookies, but this recipe intrigued me.

Wow!! What have I been missing?-These!  These are FANTASTIC! Thank you DR AMY!

They didn't spread and were perfect.  I used my large metal baking sheets with unbleached parchment paper.  I used the Pampered Chef small scoop and baked at 325 for 11 minutes (I let the oven come to temperature and then let it sit for an additional 10 minutes - for even baking... NEVER put in the first batch of cookies as soon as the oven beeps)

I tweaked it with some suggestions previously mentioned and added some of my own:
I do not let the butter soften.  I leave it out for 10-15 minutes, let it remain firm and whip it for 6-8 minutes.  The heat from the beaters is more than enough to make it light and creamy- I find it is less greasy this way.
I used 1 1/2 C. flour, 1 t. baking soda, 2 shakes of the salt shaker and 3 1/2 cup of ground quick oats (I used my cuisinart and grinded the oats to a gritty powder).
I did not use nuts- added extra handfuls of chocolate chips.  I only had the semi-sweet on hand, I think milk chocolate would make these even better

My son (who likes all of my cookies loved these).. his best friend- one of the pickiest 4 year olds I have ever met (is there another 4 year old who doesn't like pizza?? I don't think so!) also loved them.  That is a testiment in itself!

I will definately make these over and over!  My new favorite, hand-me-down recipe!

text:
I really loved this recipe.  I was looking for a good, chewy oatmeal cookie that would allow for some add-ins and that's exactly what I got.  I made them exactly as stated, and ended up with 49 nice sized cookies.  I followed the basic recipe to the T, but changed the add-ins: 1c semi-sweet chocolate chips, 1c toasted almond slivers, and 1c dried cherries.  I also used almond extract instead of vanilla, to emphasize the almond flavor.  With the additions, since chocolate and cherries are both a little sweet, I felt that the amount of salt was good.  However if you're just making a basic oatmeal cookie, you will want to cut down on the salt.  Also, if your cookies are coming out flat and burning it is likely because you are over mixing (or over creaming), or because your dough has gotten too wet or too warm ... all of these things can thin out your dough and create a flatter cookie.  I'm happy to say that mine turned out great.  I did end up having to cook mine for 15 minutes, rather than the stated 12 minutes, because for my oven 12min was just not enough.  So many things can go wrong with baking, even the temperature outside plays a part in how your items turn out.  If you didn't get a good result the first time, you might want to try again rather than just throw this recipe out.

text:
First of all, thanks for the recipe.  I loosely followed the recipe because I used salted butter and did not add extra salt or nuts.  I also put in twice as much vanilla extract and added cinnamon to make them a bit spicier.  

I know that this is often regarded as incorrect, but for this recipe, I melted the butter down a bit more than usual before I creamed it with the sugar and extract.  In fact, the butter was a bit warm and very soft when I creamed it with the brown and white sugar.  I know that this is basic, but mix only one egg in at a time after that.  The result was a heavenly, and very light butter/sugar mixture.  I also mixed the baking soda into the flour with a fork so that it was evenly distributed before mixing everything together. 

I then chilled the mixture for ten minutes and rolled my cookies into walnut sized balls (or slightly larger).  I feel like this helped to keep the cookies aloft when they were baking.  The first batch baked for 12 minutes at 325 were a bit gooey in the middle so I let them finish cooking on the pan. I actually think that when they cooled, the 12 minute cookies turned out just fine.  The cookies I tried for 13-14 minutes were perfectly acceptable, but a bit too dry the next day.  I have not tried the extra flour or baking soda, but I think that it would definitely give the cookies a bit more body, if that's what you are into.

text:
I have made this recipe a dozen times and they are the closest thing to the perfect chocolate chip oatmeal cookie I've ever had! They are my go-to - without fail, they are moist, slightly crispy around the edges, and full of flavor. The only slight modifications I make are as follows: I don't ever buy white flour or white sugar so in their place in the recipe I use raw sugar and unbleached 100% whole wheat flour (I'm partial to King Arthur brand). I also halve the salt to 1/2 tsp and because I like a cookie that's not 'fluffy' I leave the flour and baking soda as is even though many reviewers add more. Perfection! I eat a whole food, primarily plant based, minimally refined, minimally processed, diet most of the time.... but every once and a while you just have to have a "splurge" item and these cookies are absolutely it for me. Yum! Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Follow the tips and these were wonderful!! Increases flour to 11/2 cups, increase baking soda to 1 tsp, added half tsp cinnamon and only 1tsp real vanilla. Only used half tsp salt. Used only 2cups quick oats. I added 1 tsp molasses. Split the cookie dough and made one with choc chips and the other with pecans & golden raisins. Refrigerated dough 30 mins before and baked on parchment paper in my electric oven on 345, 9-10 mins. Do not over cook them! Cool full 5 mins before placing on cooling rack. Keep dough in fridg. 1 also added 1/4 tsp baking powder. Slightly under cook them. They were a Hugh hit. Very soft and chewy and great flavor, a keeper! Make them a bit bigger cause they do shrink a bit, they spread a little not a super thick cookie, but I like how they turned out. Only used the mixer for the butter and sugars and eggs, then mixed with spatula, don't over beat the dough. Will make these again and again! Thanks!

Great recipe! I did follow other reviewers and added 1/2 cup flour, 1/2 tsp baking soda, and less salt by 1/2 tsp. I also mixed by hand as I mixed most of my cookies by hand. I find using a hand mixer or food processor makes the batter too funny, and cookie batter should be more firm. Cookies came out nicely, not flat at all.

This recipe on its own is delicious! The butter makes them spread out thin, just let them cool 5-10 minutes before taking them off the pan. (I use a silicone baking mat for cookies; well worth the $9 I spent - easy cleanup and easy to remove.) Instead of walnuts, I added about 3/4 pecans but grinded them up in a food processor first. The pecans made them taste great all around w/out big chunks of nuts. I've made 3 batches now, but I use less butter than the recipe calls for (about 1.5 cups). They still taste supreme even if your measurements aren't exact. My notes aside, these cookies are amazing and you won't be able to eat just one, or two...! Thanks Panthera!

text:
These cookies as they stand in this recipe are not to my liking. They came out SO flat. I also had to keep them in there for 17 minutes because they were raw and watery after 12 (and I keep my cooking stone in the oven as it preheats). I took them out at 17 because they were starting to burn on the sides but the middle was still raw. They were so unreasonably sticky I had to scrape of the cooking stone when I finally got the cookies off. Then they fell through the cooling racking into a pile of crumbs. A pile of crumbs that tasted bland. Luckily, I thought the salt was too much just reading the recipe and hadn't put that much in.

So I scrolled down to read the reviews (which I would have done sooner if I realized that the 5 star rating was so unjustly given) and saw that everyone was adding flour to the recipe to make it passable. So I did, and more baking soda, and more sugar, and a little cinnamon, and now the cookies are only kind of blah. 

Do not make these.

The BEST oatmeal cookies I've ever tasted. I followed the advice from the reviews and added 1/4 c. flour and 1/2 tsp baking soda. I omitted the nuts and chocolate chips. The cooking time is about right; the cookies should come out of the oven when their centers still look raw and are only stable around the edges. Let them cool on the baking trays (I use parchment paper or silicone baking mats). These are so delicious and chewy- I promise!
UPDATE: I tried Beth's Spicy Oatmeal Raisin Cookies, which were even better! They were the same recipe as my modifications to this one, except baked at a higher temperature so they wouldn't spread as much.

text:
I gave the recipe as written 4 stars because of the previous reviewers changes, but the end result 5 stars! I feel that the extra flour and baking soda necessary.  I however, I only reduced the salt by 1/4 tsp.  I found this to be a good amount; any more may have been too much salt.  I also added a 1/2 c. more of chocolate chips.  I also upped the oven temp. to 350, and baked for the written 12 min.  You can tell they are done when the edges are just starting to turn a light golden brown.  

With these additions, I also found it helpful to chill the dough for an hour before putting onto a parchment paper-lined cookie sheet.  Another helpful tip is to flatten the balls of dough slightly because they don't flatten as well on their own.  

Overall, a very yummy cookie...chewy yet soft and fluffy!

text:
So... I am giving this recipe a 5 star with my revisions. You must use 1 3/4 cup flour, 1 tsp of baking soda and cut the salt in half to 1/2tsp.  Also, for a twist, I added 1/2 cup of semi sweet chocolate and 1/2 cup butterscotch morsels.  I also scooped with an ice cream scooper onto baking sheet and because the cookies were larger (due to spooning with the ice cream scooper), I baked on 335 degrees for 16 minutes. They are going to look like they are not done but they are. Be sure to let them cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes after removing them from the oven.  Super good!

Great cookies!  After reading previous reviews I made the following changes.  
1 3/4 cups flour
1 tsp baking soda
1/2 tsp salt
I made half with dried cranberries and raisins and other half with choc. chips and toffee bits. I've been looking for a recipe like this! I did my research and scrolled down through the comments and reviews.  I baked these today for the first time, and took the multiple advice of increasing the flour (I used 1 3/4 cups) and baking soda (to 1 tsp), and decreased the salt to 1/4 tsp.  I also omitted the nuts, my son has a no-nut policy at his school.  So now these are the perfect addition to his lunch box!  Finally, I baked at 335 for 13 minutes, perfect.  They came out of the oven looking undercooked, but I left them on the pans for 5-10 mins to cool, and they ended up soft, chewy and perfect.  This is now my standard oatmeal cookie recipe!

text:
Great chewy cookie! 5 stars with these few changes. First time I made these I followed the recipe and loved the texture, yet I found them too salty. I just finished baking them for the second time, (last batch is still cooling on  the wire rack) and I've already eaten three. Here are the changes I have made. 1- no salt. 2- Used apple sauce instead of butter. Had I had any fructose left I would have substituted it for the sugar. In any recipe that calls for sugar, you can substitute it by using half the amount of fructose. You'll never know the difference. My sweetaholic hubby doesn't know I cut the fat and the sweet from his treats. Fructose can be found in a natural food/health store.

text:
Tasty oatmeal cookie!  My whole family loved them.  We hardly had any left after they cooled completely because everyone kept coming back for another.  They were chewy and delicious.  I followed others advice and added 1/2 c. extra flour, 1/2 tsp. extra baking soda and cut the salt to about 1/4 tsp. I live in humid part of Texas so my cookies tend to spread out more when I use only butter so I used 1/2 butter & 1/2 shortening.  This seems to make my cookies stand up better.  I made my cookies about 2 inches each (so it made more than the stated 3 1/2 dozen).  I baked them at 325 degrees for 10 min to get cookies that stayed soft & chewy even after they cooled down and did not spread out flat.  They looked underdone when I took them out of the oven but I left them on the cookie sheet for 5 minutes before transferring to a cooling rack.  They turned out perfectly!  I will be making these again soon.

I love this recipe.  I have modified it to make it healthier.  I use part white flour, wheat flour and wheat germ.  I use rolled oats and Smart Balance Stick Butter.  They are still wonderful.  In fact, the Smart Balance Butter Sticks hold the shape better.  Just remember to chill the dough for at least 1 hour before baking.  I love to have these as a quick after-school snack.  Therefore, I usually make the full recipe.  I chill the dough, drop out cookies, stick in the freezer for 1 hour and then stick them unbaked in a large ziploc bag.  Just bake for 14-16 minutes when frozen.  They also hold their shape better too!  These have been a staple in my pregnancy, hence the need to make them a little bit healthier!!!

userID:
1157089
Display Name:
MIUKAT
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2

14

139
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/112727.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out great! I'm giving it 4 stars because I did make slight changes.  First, even though it doesn't specify, you have to cream the butter and sugar till it's really fluffy.  This will help make your cookies puffy.  I only made a half recipe, but used a little more flour than was stated.  (It was only about 2 T more for half, about 1/4 c. extra if I would have made a full recipe.)  Lastly, I changed the baking soda to baking powder.  Baking soda helps to raise acid ingredients like buttermilk, and this recipe doesn't have acid ingredients.    Also, I used whole grain hot cereal from Trader Joe's, which looks like oatmeal, but has different grains, like rye, barley, oats, and wheat, just to add more texture.  As a hot cereal, it is chewier and heartier, so I wanted to see if it would add those characteristics to a cookie, too.  The mix was stiff and dry-ish.  I scooped out large balls of dough, and flattened the tops with the palm of my hand, just to help them along.  I baked them at 350 for about 12 minutes, noticed that the tops weren't browning as fast as the bottom, and put them one rack higher than the middle to finish cooking.  I was afraid that 325 would dry them out by the time they were browned.  Hope this helps.

5

text:
I'm usually awful at making cookies from scratch but this recipe came out absolutely perfect for me. If you don't want your cookies to spread, you do not have to change the recipe by adding flour or oatmeal. To keep the cookies super thick, just chill the dough before baking and make sure your cookie sheet is at room temperature or colder. I experimented with baking these cookies in different ways and my personal favorite is with cold dough on a hot cookie sheet. That combo kept the centers thick and chewy but allowed the edges to spread a bit while baking so they got a little crispy.

This recipe was easy, and very yummy.  I used butter flavored vege. shortening, instead of the butter.  I cut the salt to 1/2 teaspoon, upped the chocolate chips to 1 1/2 cups, and added 1/4 teaspoon baking powder.  I mixed the dough by traditional bowl and spoon method (not in a mixer) and let the dough chill for the time it took to preheat the oven (about 10 minutes).    I baked them on ungreased fiberglass baking mats.I had no problem with the cookies spreading.  I'll make these again.

text:
One of my favorites!  I fix the flattening problem by popping the bowl of dough in the fridge for 10-15 minutes before rolling them into balls.  This firms up that melting butter in the dough so it holds together a little better during the baking process.  I NEVER have problems when I do that. In fact, I have to flatten the little balls with a spatula first to keep them from coming out too round.  I will continue to make these over and over again!

text:
Delicious! I was forced to make some odd substitutions but these cookies still turned out great! I didn’t have enough butter on hand so I used butter-flavored Crisco instead. (I added 6 tsp of water to the Crisco before I creamed it with the sugars.) I also discovered I didn’t have enough oatmeal so I used about 1 and a half cups of regular oatmeal and then I emptied 2 packs of instant apple-cinnamon breakfast oatmeal into a colander, shook out the apple-cinnamon flavoring, and added that oatmeal (along with its dried apples) to the mix. I was pretty sure the cookies were going to be mediocre at best, but WOW. They really turned out great. I will make these again and again. I will probably keep the Crisco in place of the butter, but I will double check my supply of oatmeal before I start baking next time

Awesome cookies!  And I have a hard time finding cookies I like.  If you use butter flavor crisco instead of butter or margarine, you won't have that spreading problem.  The cookies stay in a uniform shape and are still chewy.  I made the following changes based on other reviews:  1 1/2 C. flour, 1 t. baking soda, 3/4 t. salt.  I added about 1/2 cup more oats (I used the old fashioned kind), 3/4 c. chocolate chips, 1/2 c. rice crispies, and 1/4 C.  coconut--my family loves coconut and omitted the nuts because I didn't have any...I would try pecans instead of walnuts because I think walnuts have a funny taste sometimes. I will definately make these over and over!

These are really good cookies. I did, however, make some changes to fit our tastes. I added extra vanilla (1 Tbsp), 1 tsp of cinnamon, 1/2 tsp nutmeg (next time I might add a little extra of thse to spices as I really like a spiced oatmal cookie). I didn't feel like chocolate, so I used currants (1 cup) instead (half way through making the cookies I realized that I was out of rasins. oops!) I poured boiling water over them and let them stand 10 mins before sraining them and adding them to the dough. They got nice and soft and went nicely with the chewy cookie. I'm not a big walnut fan, so I used slivered almonds instead. Really good! Added a nice crunch. I might actually add a tsp of almond extract next time, I think it would really bring all the flavors together nicley. Anyway, they turned out really well. I made them last night, and there are only 2 cookies left tonight, and it's just the 2 of us! *LoL* My boyfriend is the cookie monster, I swear.
Thank you for this tasty recipe. I'll deffinetly be making it again!

text:
Hi, I checked the difference in the type of oats and found the following info: quick oats = quick-cooking oats = quick oatmeal = quick-cooking oatmeal = easy oats    Notes:   These are thin flakes of oatmeal that cook up in about three or four minutes.  They're a good choice for oatmeal cookies.   Substitutes:  rolled oats (More nutritious and chewy, takes longer to cook. If substituting rolled oats for quick oats in a cookie recipe, consider refrigerating the dough for 20 minutes before baking-- otherwise the cookies may become too flat and thin) OR instant oats (This contains additional flavorings, and is less chewy. It also takes less time to cook)

Love this recipe, so do my kids. We made the following changes: used Crisco instead of butter, almond extract instead of vanilla, added 1 tsp. cinnamon, 1 1/2 cups flour, 1 tsp. baking soda, 1/2 tsp. salt, old fashioned oats for quick cooking, 1 1/2 cups walnuts, 2 cups chocolate chips. We use an ice cream scoop to get cookies onto parchment paper and bake for 13-15 minutes. Makes big, thick cookies that DO NOT spread too much. One is often enough. We bake 2 dozen and freeze 2 dozen 'balls' for quick and easy treats. All around, a truly great cookie base. Thanks.

Great recipe. These are the best oatmeal cookies I've had in a long time.  I followed the other reviewers' instructions by increasing flour to 
1 1/2 c., baking soda to 1 tsp. and decreasing salt to 1/2 tsp.  I used salted butter in my recipe also.  Not sure if this makes a difference to the recipe, but I sifted the flour, baking soda and salt together and I pulsed the oatmeal in the food processor before adding it to the mix(following a suggestion from another recipe).  If you like raisins with your oatmeal cookies, these taste absolutely delicious with golden raisins.

Any way good recipe, better with the modifications.

text:
awesome cookie. crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. read the reviews and made the following changes.  

1. used half cup butter, half cut shortening. 2. increased baking soda to 1 teaspoon. 3. decreased salt to 1/2 teaspoon (used salted butter). 4. increased oatmeal to 3 1/2 cups. 5. created spoonfuls and put batter in the freezer for 10 minutes.

place balls on the cookie sheet and smash just little. bake at 325 degrees for 13-15 minutes. (took it out when tops were golden brown)

don't forget the last step. leave on the cookie sheet for a few minutes after taking out of the oven. this is key.

text:
I cannot stress enough how important it is to READ THE REVIEWS.   Many people are providing useful tips that could save you hours of frustration and prevent you from wasting your ingredients.  For example, many people said to increase the flour and decrease the salt and that's exactly what I did.  My cookies came out  great !!  Also, please remember that all ovens are not created equal.  In fact, Cook's Illustrated Magazine tested oven temperatures and found that while set to the  same temperature, the internal temperature of different ovens can vary by as much as 90 degrees!!  You can't always follow the recipe as stated and expect  perfect results. I had to bake my cookies at 350 for 10 minutes to get the results I wanted.  So take the time to read the reviews and remember that  you may still have to make some adjustments.  Don't give up on a recipe after one bad experience because with a few adjustments you might find a gem that you will love for a lifetime.

text:
These made a pretty good cookie. Many reviewers reported a flat cookie. Common causes of too-flat cookies include: Baking on too low of a temperature (I noticed this recipe said 325 instead of the more common 350); not enough flour - I added an extra 1/4 cup; and the butter is too warm when it hits the oven (this is why chilling the dough before baking may help); ineffective leavening due to unreactive baking soda / powder. Baking soda is alkaline (basic), and needs some sort of acid (e.g. cream of tartar, lemon juice, vinegar, etc) in the recipe to cause the cookie to rise ( acid + base = chemical reaction when mixed with wet ingredients). Vanilla extract is a weak acid, though perhaps not acidic enough to cause the desired chemical reaction in this recipe. I suspect this is why reviewers who doubled the baking soda, with double the usual amount of vanilla, had better results. 

I substituted 1/2 tsp. baking powder (which is essentially a mixture of acid and base that is activated when wet) for the soda with good results. 

As well I baked my cookies for 9 minutes at 350 to ensure they were soft and chewy.

text:
Okay I haven't even made the cookie yet and everyone is saying to add more flour and baking soda. 
If you should know, yes flour adds stability but baking soda adds spread of the cookie (if you add too much.
If you want less spread and more of a stable round cookie, don't put as much sugar. 
Sugar melts and makes the cookie spread and then when it dries, the sugar crystallizes which makes it crunchy. 
This recipe should be followed and you should end with a thin chewy cookie with crunchy sides. 
This is no regular fluffy oatmeal cookie.  
I love this recipe how it is.

text:
This is my go-to cookie recipe. These are always a hit at home and when I share them. A friend told me "This is what a cookie is supposed to be like!" The secret to a rounder cookie is I prep the dough first, then put it in the freezer while I preheat the oven (about 10 minutes). Cold dough is key! I then use a melon baller and make however many I need at the time and store the remaining dough in a tupperware in the fridge so it's easily accessible and quick to bake. These bake perfectly at 325 for 12 minutes in my gas oven. With the small melon baller I have, this recipe makes about 5 dozen cookies consistently. Oh, and I always skip the nuts.

THis was agood start, but it lacked a lot of flavor.   made oatmeal cookies many, many years ago.  It was my mother's recipe that got lost when she died. after more than 50 years, I decided to recreate the recipe.  I remember some of the key ingredients and after about 8 tries, I got a very good Oatmeal, Raisin, Walnut cookie.  The big secret in making the cookie is the use of a combination of spices.  I use 1 t. ground cinnamon, 1/2 t. ground ginger, 1/2 t. ground nutmeg and  1/4 t. ground cloves.   I also use both baking soda and baking powder.  I use buttermilk, 1 egg and 1 egg yolk and half of the flour is bread flower.  I guarantee that cookie is a winner.  If you want the recipe, send me an e-mail.

text:
I was craving chocolate sans the guilt, so I was really excited to finally try this recipe out!  I cut the recipe in half, used whole wheat flour instead (wanted to feel the least guilt possible lol), used Rob's Red Mill Muesli to kick it up a notch instead of regular oatmeal, and did not use chopped walnuts since there are a whole bunch of nuts in the Muesli.  Scooped the dough into little balls and froze before baking then placed them onto parchment paper (for the gooey center).  It seemed like it took forever for these to bake, so I ended up raising the temperature to 350 which seemed to do the trick.  I then let them cool on a wire rack and placed in a sealed container.  Brought them into work two days later and they were still SO soft!  They taste so different/just as good/maybe better cooled a couple days later!  I am shocked that this "healthier" version tasted this good.

text:
Delicious!!! I made these once and will be making again. I think I've found my basic go to recipe. I followed other suggestions by adding more flour (I like to use semi-whole wheat). I didn't have baking soda (hard to find in France) so used double the amount of baking powder. I also like to add a mix of spices, usually 1/2 teaspoon each of cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg and ginger. Usually when I make cookies I like to set the dough in the fridge for about half an hour. They turn out less flat. I also like to make little balls of dough and then freeze them. That way I won't eat all the cookies in one sitting and can cook a few at a time when my little chocolate lover requests cookies (my other son wants nothing to do with chocolate or cookies, so it doesn't make sense for me to make a whole batch). Next time, I want to add raisins in with the chocolate.

text:
Excellent with a few alterations. Like the other reviewers, I found it best to add 1/2 cup of flour and reduce the salt to 1/2 teaspoon. In addition, I felt like the first batch of cookies was missing something, so I turned to my oatmeal raisin cookie recipes and decided to add in 1 teaspoon of cinnamon. The cinnamon just adds a savory flavor to the cookies and makes them POP! I really enjoy soft, chewy cookies so I usually bake mine a few minutes less than the baking time in recipes. For these cookies, I found 8 - 9 minutes at 350 degrees to be the "sweet spot." As with any cookie, keeping them sealed tightly in a cool, dry location is the key to freshness. I also tend to add a slice of bread to maintain moisture. With the alterations, these didn't last long at our house!

This is a great recipe. I have made it several times now and gotten tons of compliments each time. I did modify it very slightly by decreasing the salt to 1/2 tsp (the first time I made them they were just a bit too salty for our taste) and I use my "secret" ingredient of using only Guittard Milk Chocolate chips. But other than those personal taste substitutions, they are perfect! I also wanted to add my personal tip: chill your cookie dough for an hour if you can, then loosely shape into a balls and flatten them bit with your hand when you put them on the cookie sheet. This will prevent your cookies from flattening out and still give them a substantial "middle" worth biting into!

text:
I made this recipe exactly as instructed. The only thing I did differently was add my own favorites, 1 cup of butterscotch chips, handful of raisins & sliced almonds. I didn't have any walnuts so I substituted with sliced almonds.  When cookies were in the oven I started reading some of the reviews and noticed all the variations. My main concern was the salt! When I decided to make oatmeal cookies I saw that this recipe had a lot of stars and began making them because I had most of the ingredients on hand. Then realized as I was reading that many had issues on the cookies flattening and thus resulting in different variations. Many review talked about too much salt. I did not have any issues as I did make them exactly as instructed...including the salt and my butter had salt. Thank goodness they came out fantastic!  Baking with the right pans/ cookie sheets makes all the difference on your final results. I baked these cookies at 325*  I started timer for 10 min because every oven is different and I can usually tell by sight if they need to bake longer, but I always start with minimum time then continue checking every 2 min until ready. Then set cookies on cool racks immediately after.  This recipe is a keeper!  Thanks for sharing Panthera ;p

text:
I gave the recipe 4 stars as it is written, but I think it is 5 with the changes I made. I followed others' suggestions and used 1 3/4 cups flour, 1 tsp baking soda, and 1/2 tsp salt.  I used 1 cup wheat flour and 3/4 cup white flour, and I think I'll try all wheat flour next time. I also omitted the walnuts and added a 2nd cup of chocolate chips. I'm a chocolate lover, and 1 cup just didn't seem to be enough. I refrigerated the dough overnight, and baked them the next day for 14 minutes at 325. They were absolutely perfect. They hardly spread at all and rose up thick and chewy. I made them fairly small. I used a cookie scoop that is a little more than a tablespoon, and the cookies spread to about a 2 inch diameter and were 3/4 to 1 inch thick. Delicious! Everyone raved about them.

These are great.  I halved the recipe.  Only changes I made were adding cranberries (in place of nuts) and white chocolate chips (in place of chocolate chips).  I had an Ocean Spray cranberry and white chocolate cookie recipe, but I didn't like the texture of them.  These were much more to my liking. I just made these about an hour ago, and they turned out great! They are so soft, they almost seem undercooked at just 12 minutes, but once they sit a bit they get more firm. 

Like some reviewers said, I made the modification of 1 1/2 cups flour, 1 tsp baking soda and 1/2 tsp salt. I also used a mix of white and semisweet chocolate chips. I will be making them again.

UPDATE: I had to give 5 stars. These cookies are the bomb! They stay super soft and moist. If you layer them in a container, place a paper towel between layers so they won't stick together.

text:
This is in reference to some concerns I've seen in the reviews.  For the butter lovers:  If you use salted butter, only use 1/2 tsp. of salt in the recipe because a stick of salted butter has 1/4 tsp. of salt in it  already.  Also, if you don't want your cookies to spread out, don't use butter.... use shortening.  Butter has a very low melting point and the cookies spread out before the binding takes place.  Shortening makes higher, more full, chewy cookies.  Hope this helps.  By the way, loved the cookies.

text:
My favourite oatmeal cookie recipe yet! I followed the other suggestions to increase baking soda to 1tsp, and increase flour to 1 3/4 cup. I used pecans instead of walnuts because that's all I had, but I toasted them first which gives a richer flavour. I also mildly chopped the chocolate chips so pieces aren't as huge and the chocolate flavour is more subtle in the cookies. I reduced the chocolate chips to 3/4 cup also; I find 1 cup too sweet. 

The first time I made these, friends came over the day after and all of the cookies disappeared! They are a hit!

I would love to do 4.5 stars, because this recipe is THAT good. Almost perfect. I added 1tsp of cinnamon (a must in oatmeal for me). Also, after I saw how loose the batter was before i added the oats, I did add 1/4c more flour and 1/4 tsp baking soda, with those additions & bumping temp up to 335 they were PERFECT. After the 1st batch (which was a gift), i immediately made a second for my family. The only difference was, I used 2 sticks of margarine, because of dairy allergy, 2nd batch was 1 stick butter and 1 stick margarine. That was the only difference, and they totally FLATTENED OUT. Very dissapointing! So, butter totally made the difference, had to refrigerate the dough and turn the oven down. They did taste great flat, I just prefer a more rounded cookie.

text:
These cookies are amazing, and should be given 5 stars, but I made some changes as others suggested. I added 1/4c flour, and omitted the salt (because my butter is salted). I also used old fashioned oats, as I didn't have any quick-cook oats. But my cookies turned out *perfectly*- soft and chewy and a little crunchy around the edges. And they did not flatten out at all- make sure you mix the wet ingredients with the blender for 4-5 mins, and only *just* incorporate the dry ingredients. I threw my dough in the fridge until I had time to bake them, and I am so so so glad with how they turned out. This will be the only oatmeal chocolate chip cookie I ever make again!

text:
First of all, I made the following alterations:
1/2 tsp. sea salt
1/2 cup olive oil (I didn't have enough butter!)
11.5 oz. MILK chocolate chips (1 bag)
Bake 18 minutes

Secondly, this recipe is awesome! 

I'm surprised that some people had trouble with spreading (altitude maybe?) because my batter was so thick that I had to roll up my sleeves and work the last cup of oatmeal and chocolate chips in by hand; there was no way the stuff would stir. In the oven, the cookies did not spread at all, but rather puffed up a bit.

I'm pretty sensitive to things that are too salty, so even though I didn't use butter, I still cut Panthera's amount of salt in half per other reviewers' recommendations.

I'm sampling a cookie right now, and it's chewy, perfectly proportioned, and not too dense/heavy. I'm a "dunker" and it's great dipped in milk...it gets soft, but doesn't fall apart which is something I was worried about since the cookies are a bit on the crumbly side. Glorious.

The flavor is amazing. As long as you don't use a SUPER strong/aromatic/olive-y olive oil, you can't even tell that there's no butter. Even if you do use strong EVOO (like I did) you can taste it very slightly but it's not unpleasant...it's interesting and doesn't take away from the awesomeness at all! In fact, at first I wasn't so sure, but other cookie connoisseurs who sampled olive oil cookies actually preferred them over the cookies with butter!

All in all (even though I didn't follow the recipe exactly)...A+!

I increased the flour by a half cup and the baking soda by a 1/2 tbsp as others suggested and decreased the salt.  I also added a 1/2 tsp of cinnamon (highly recommend) and left the nuts out. The absolute BEST oatmeal cookies ever!  Like some others, I also added the extra 1/2 cup of flour and extra 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda, and reduced the salt to 1/2 teaspoon.  I followed Marie C.'s directions and creamed the butter and sugar 4-1/2 minutes, and then stirred the dry ingredients in by hand. text:
I followed the advice of other reviewers and increased the flour by 1/2 cup, baking soda by a 1/2T, and decreased the salt to 1/2tsp.  Also made sure to cream butter, sugar, and eggs together until fluffy before hand-stirring dry ingredients in.  After baking for exactly 12 min I removed cookies immediately from baking sheet...waiting for 5 min would've left them overdone.  Also, I chilled the dough in the fridge in between filling baking sheets, this seemed to help keep from spreading.  Easy recipe with a great balanced flavor and good texture!

Do not listen to the people saying to add more flour!!  As someone else suggested, simply chill the dough around 2 hrs to prevent flat, crispy cookies. text:
These cookies are delicious and easy to make. Some adjustments I made: - 4 teaspoons of vanilla extract for stronger vanilla flavour - Reduced salt to 3/4 of a teaspoon as they were slightly salty - No walnuts for allergy reasons - Used milk chocolate chips or reduced the amount of semisweet chocolate chips added as 1 cup made the cookies too sweet and overpowered the taste of the cookie - Let cookie cool for 10+ minutes. Will cause cookie to stay moist and chewier longer.   Great recipe. Fun to play around with ingredients. Always a sellout at parties.

I loved the saltiness, but as others have said, omit the salt if you don't like salty cookies and are using salted butter.

Before making these cookies, I read some of the reviews, so right off the bat I added the extra baking soda and flour, and cut the salt in half. The first batch that I put in the oven came out really gooey, which is yummy, but they were a little underdone. text:
Wow, these are some pretty good cookies. I made them for my local garden walk and LOVED them. However, I did run into a few things, I love my cookies cooked and soft but not crunchy, and I found that my cookies came out looking like that but the bottoms were still really crunchy. Also, this is NOT a good recipe to put into the refridgerator for a few hours before you bake, because while I was waiting for my cookies to bake I found that the oats in the dough, seed to absorb some of the moisture in the cookies, so I would advise to make the cookies as soon as you make the dough. You may also notice that, like I did, the batter is really loose and unformed, I would NOT recommend adding more flour because my cookies already turned out a bit dry. However, these are among my favorite cookies. YUM, YUM!!

Interesting story: My son came to me and asked me why there aren't any potato chips crushed up in cookies. I thought that was a mighty good question because potato chips+chocolate is made of win. So, I picked this recipe to be my guinea pig. We made minor changes, cut the recipe in half, ground the oatmeal down in my blender to make a "flour" consistancy, used "chunk" Hershey's chips and subbed crushed potato chips in place of the nuts. Really simple changes and oh, my. Was it good! And to show my son that yes, it can be done. Great thing about the ground up oatmeal? It kind of takes on a nutty consistancy so it seems like oatmeal but you're mind and mouth thinks it's nuts. This was a good recipe to use.

text:
Great recipe! I made some adjustments that other raters have suggested. I used 1-1/2 cups flour and 1 tsp baking soda, only a pinch of salt (I used Smart Balance, so I didn't think it needed too much salt), and I didn't over mix the dough. I also added about 1/4 tsp cinnamon to the flour/baking soda mixture before I combined it with the sugar/butter/egg/vanilla mixture. After baking them I feel like 3 cups of oats might have been too much, but they are still really good regardless. Apparently 335 degrees for 12 minutes worked perfectly. text:
VERY VERY VERY good! I used unsalted butter, increased flour by another 1/2 cup, and increased baking soda an additional 1/2 teaspoon, based on reviews. Omitted nuts, but will add next time for one rockin' good cookie! If you don't add nuts, try adding **just a few** more choc chips to avoid some "blank" bites. Definitely use semi-sweet because it's a sweet-tasting cookie overall. Due to some comments on spreading, I put the dough in the fridge between batches... even though spreading wasn't an issue on the first batch. After great success with this oatmeal version, I don't think I'll make the regular choc chip cookie ever again - oatmeal really makes a satisfying cookie! This is my new cookie standard! THANKS!

text:
I set out trying to find a recipe that would be as close to Kashi's Oatmeal Dark Chocolate Chip Cookies as possible.   BINGO!!! I found it!  NOTE: I took the advice of other reviewers and added an extra 1/4 cup of flour, omitted the salt (used salted butter), and increased the baking soda to 1 tsp.  Also, I added one cup of chopped pecans instead of walnuts (personal preference)and used 1 cup of Hershey's Special Dark Chocolate chips.  As the dough is very thick and bulky to work with, stirring it was next to impossible. So I slid on a pair of plastic gloves and kneaded the dough by hand (it is important not to over stir this batter). Worked like a charm!  I imagined when I took the first batch out of the oven they were going to be good. After I tasted one, I knew for sure.  Very good cookie, nice and crunchy on the outside and soft and chewy on the inside.

Delicious!

Instead of white sugar I used splenda (use a little less if you use splenda) and i threw in an extra pinch of baking soda.  And lastly I didn't use any salt because I used salted butter.

text:
I've made these twice now and think they are the best oatmeal cookies ever!  The first time I made them I followed advise from other reviews and they were perfect.  This last time they came out a little flat cause I didn't follow all the suggestions.  So here's what to do: make sure to beat the sugars and butter for about 4 minutes and then mix all the rest by hand and not too much so the cookies won't flatten and become hard.  Add about 1/8 cup more flour and I added more choc. chips and no nuts.  Make sure the cookies are not too big, about 1 1/2 inch ball and don't over bake them (that can make them hard too).  This should give you a perfect cookies that you can't stop eating.

Excellent oatmeal cookie recipe! My whole family loves these. I made a couple of simple adjustments to the recipe. 

1. reduce the sugar; 3/4c. brown and 1/4c white sugar

2. Reduce chocolate chips (to about 1/2c)

3. Add 1/2 - 3/4 c dried cranberries

The mix of chocolate and cranberries is fantastic and gives the cookie a boost of colour!

This is an awesome recipe!!! My first ever cookie that isn't overly sweet or salty or flat and crunchy.  I followed the other suggestions and also the half portion for oatmeal and other half for shredded coconut.  I did not have vanilla extract, but did use the caramel syrup from a bottle!!  Drizzled it on top of the butter (from fridge popped into oven for 30 secs) and the sugar mixture.  I did however have this Wholesome organic cane sugar?  So with this, you usually have to use more to acquire the 'american sweet' taste, but did not do that, stuck with the measurements and came out perfectly.  I popped mine in after mixing everything, so maybe for those whose are flat, the butter may have sat too long outside?  I've had this problem with other recipes when I forget how long the butter is out.  So now I just pop it in the microwave for 30 secs if it's 2 sticks, one stick I think 10-15 secs, depending on the microwave.  Anyway, babbling too much here, but thank you for this recipe, and thank everyone for their suggestions, it worked out!!!  Love this website! :)

text:
I didn't find these cookies chewy, but they were still good.  I'm not sure if I made my cookies too big, but I had to bake them for 14 min.  They were still a little raw at 12, but maybe that's what makes them chewy.  I increased the flour (1 1/4 white & 1/2 c whole wheat), soda, and reduced salt as suggested. I also added 2 Tbsp ground Flax Seed and omitted the nuts.  I loved the vanilla flavour in the cookies.  I'm used to adding spices to my oatmeal cookies, so these were different for us but good.  UPDATE: I was disappointed with the cookies the next day.  They turned hard and dry - "granola like". I tried this recipe again, but reduced the flour (put in 1 1/3 cups - 1 c white and 1/3 c wh. wheat) and added 1 tsp. cinnamon and 2 dashes of ground cloves, and kept the soda at 1 tsp. and again added flax seed.  They turned out much better and baked perfectly at 12 min. Anymore than 1 1/2 cups flour, I think is just too much.  The dough was very hard to mix the first time.  Hooray they're chewy!

text:
Very yummy cookies-but did some fine tuning.  I did add an extra 1/4 cup flour and an extra 1/2 tsp baking soda.  In this hot weather-cookies tend to flatten easier so I added an extra 1/4 tsp baking powder to that as well(if it's not humid I would leave out the powder).  Picture perfect shape to these cookies.  I also left out the nuts and added an extra cup of chips.  I  blended my oatmeal into powder-that's my taste preference- it comes out sooo good when you do that-sometimes oatmeal leaves a weird crunch that I don't like in my oatmeal chocolate chips.  I do think if you don't up the flour and baking soda-you will be left with some flat cookies.. The end taste is fabulous.  12 min is perfect cooking time-they do look a little undercooked but rest assured they are not!

text:
With the following MODIFICATIONS, these cookies were the BEST!!  
 
In addition to the complete recipe with walnuts, choc chips, baking soda, etc. I added 1/2 tsp baking powder, 1/2 cup more flour, 1/3 cup shredded sweetened coconut, 2 Tbsp more white sugar, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/2 tsp allspice, 1/4 tsp nutmeg. Sifted the dry ingredients.  
 
Pulsed 2 cups of the 3 cups of oatmeal in the food processor for about 4 seconds.  This gave it a slightly finer, more traditional texture but it was still chewy and delicious.

text:
I have made these cookies at least a half dozen times and I keep getting requests for them at work and at home.  I followed the helpful hints and cut out the salt and increased the flour and baking soda, to 1 3/4 cups and 1 teaspoon, respectively.  and I bake them at 335 for 12min exactly , no matter what color they are I take them out .They are always chewy and delicious. (Thank you Fervent Foodie!)  I add ground flaxseed (so I can call them healthier) and sometimes I do a half of cup of raisins and a half a cup of chocolate chips.  (I love raisins in oatmeal cookies).  I definitely chill the dough at least a half an hour and they never spread, in fact, I have to smush them a little if I don't want them to look like haystacks.  Either way they re chewy and delish.

text:
I made this as written, except I halved the recipe. Oh, I used regular oats, not quick cooking. 
There's a lot to like about this cookie, its rich in flavor, chewy, crispy. It did spread quite a lot, making a thin cookie, which my mother loves. 
I baked one batch true to the recipe, then chilled the dough while waiting for the first tray to back. I also added about a tablespoon and a half of extra flour. Those cookies still spread, but slightly less. 
So next time, I might try bread flour (it absorbs more liquid) I'll use quick cooking oats (again, they absorb more liquid) and will chill the dough before baking. Hopefully that'll give me the chewy, crisp cookie without it looking like a dinner plate. :) 
And I will make it again, overall, its one of the best cookie recipes I've tried.

Wonderful recipe! I added 1/2 tsp cinnamon to the dry flour mixture before mixing wet and dry. I used mini chocolate chips in half the dough and raisins in the other half. The first batch went in the oven as soon as the dough was made, but the other batches had to wait 30 minutes or so before going in and they came out thicker than the first batch that did not rest before baking. There was one ball of dough that I rolled in my hands instead of just dropping on the parchment paper and it came out looking smoother than the others that were dropped with a spoon.

text:
For those of you getting flat cookies it may be a couple of things you are doing.  Salt is necessary in this recipe for the chemical levening process with baking soda.  If you have cut out or reduced the salt that may be the problem.
Also, don’t bake the dough immediately after making it.  The butter is too soft and melts too quickly in the oven leaving you with flat cookies.  Put the dough in the fridge for a few hours (or overnight) before baking and you will have delicious fluffy cookies!
This recipe is wonderful as is and I like a little hint of salt in the dough.  I think it adds layers to the flavor to balance the sweetness.

text:
OK...glad (but really) that I read a lot of the reviews before starting these.  I mainly followed Erin's post as I'd been thinking I'd maybe need to chill the dough before baking.  There was a Sunset world's best chocolate chip cookie some years back that was similar to this (and had cinnamon!); dough was chilled for several hours first.  Didn't have enough fridge room to do that -- 4th of July coming up, etc.  So I stuck it in the freezer for a few minutes. Did bake them for 12 minutes, although they wouldn't have come off the Silpat well at that point so I let them set a few minutes.  They spread VERY LITTLE (and I used a couple tbsp of dough for each).  Which is sort of surprising considering the large amount of butter!  The verdict?  They're GOOD -- will definitely make again!

text:
I prepared this recipe pretty much as is since I did not check any reviews before making it. I instinctively used 1/2 tsp of salt and added an extra 1/4 cup of flour. As for everything else I used the ingredients in the proportions stated. I think the outcome was awesome. The flavor and texture were both excellent and as someone mentioned, it is a pretty basic cookie recipe. I like the fact that it has oatmeal which I love. It makes for a twist in the chocolate chip cookie with the extra fiber of the oatmeal. I absolutely love it and will definitely make it again. Now my recommendations: Watch for the oven temperature and baking time. Follow both as the recipe states. The cookies will continue cooking after been taken out of the oven.  Don't over bake nor put them in an oven that is too hot this will spread your cookie without fail. It is also important to be careful with the temperature of the butter. A butter that is too soft is already too warm for this recipe yielding a spread cookie. The remnant heat of a cookie sheet renders a spread cookie. To prevent this, let cookie sheets completely cool off after removing the cookies from them. A quick way to cool off cookie sheets is by sprinkling the back of the sheet with cold water using the sprinkler of the sink. Set it aside far from the heat and put the next batch in another sheet while the first cools off. This is valid for dark or light colored baking sheets. This trick also works if you use silicone mats on your cookie sh

text:
I made a couple of minor changes as mentioned by other reviewers; flour and salt increased slightly.  What I want to. mention is that I mixed the ingredients one evening, refrigerated the dough overnight and made the cookies in the morning after bringing the dough to room temp.  They came out just perfect.  Also in forming the cookie, I scooped up the dough with my hands, formed a ball, put onto the cookie sheet and then flattened it with my hand to a 3 inch diameter.  They spread a bit in coking at 325f  but retained their shape nicely.
I’ll make these again. Thank you for the recipe.

I made a half batch. Changes to original recipe based on comments by others - increased flour to 3/4 cup (or to 1 1/2 cups for full recipe), used demerara sugar instead of light brown, and 1 cup old fashioned oats plus 1/2 cup quick oats. Increased soda to 1 tsp for 1/2 batch. Increased walnuts and chocolate chips by a bit. Decreased salt because I used salted butter. Dropped by tablespoon. Increased cooking time by 2 to 3 minutes until bottoms were light brown. Made 24 good sized cookies. My cookies did not spread Maybe a little sweet for my taste but it's a cookie. Very nice. I like a good oatmeal cookie with nuts and these are very tasty.

text:
I read the reviews as I usually do and I did follow the suggestions to add 1/2 cup more flour, 1/2 tsp more baking soda and I cut the salt to 1/2 tsp.  I chilled the dough for about 1 1/2 hours but it was pretty hard to scoop.  Next time I will chill the dough only 30 minutes.  I baked the cookies at 335 degrees for 12 minutes, but when I looked at them, I thought they looked a little too raw in the middle, so I baked them for an additional 2 minutes.  I left them on the cookie sheet for the 5 minutes, then put them on wax paper.  They were pretty chewy, but I think next time I will try baking them for just the 12 minutes.   They were really good!  Everbody at our superbowl party loved them!  I may also half the recipe next time because this made about 5-6 dozen medium sized cookies!

text:
Like everyone else, added 1/2 c of flour, increased baking soda to 1 tsp, decreased salt to 1/2 tsp. I didn't add walnuts or chocolate chips, 'cause I just didn't have any. I replaced half the butter with unsweetened applesauce. And I added several heaping spoonfuls of peanut butter, as well as a pinch of nutmeg and a good bit of cinnamon.
Put the batter in the fridge for a while. Baked them at 350 for 13 min and then let them sit on the pan for five min before moving to a cooling rack.
These cookies were PRIME. Delicious, moist, chewy, and didn't spread at all.
Although, it's not really the original recipe anymore. At all. But with these variations, the cookies were bomb. :)

THis is a special recipe.  As a rule, chocchip cookies are not my favorite but this recipe might change my mind.  This is unfortunate because I usually make Choco chip cookies so I don't eat them.  It's a very balanced cookie, great texture, love the nuttiness and oats really balances out the sweet chocolate. My changes include: 1/2cup chopped pecans, 1/2 cup chopped walnuts, 1/2 cup dark choco chunks, 1/2 cup semisweet, reduced the salt by half because I used salted Kerrygold butter, used all old fashioned oats because that's what I had, chilled the dough at least two hours.  I also weigh all my  dry ingredients.  Thank you for a wonderful recipe.  Looking forward to making this again.
