text:
This was the easiest cookie recipe I have ever worked with and I have been baking for five decades.  It is also the best oatmeal chocolate chip cookie recipe.  The only thing I would do differently the next time is make the cookies smaller.   I think I made them bigger than they should be.  I did read some of the reviews about cookies that tasted too salty and cookies that spread out and burned while baking.  I learned a long time ago never to use butter when making cookies, salted or unsalted, because that's what happened to my batch of cookies and all I had was a giant mess of crumbs.  After that I went back to my old standby of Imperial margarine.  In all of these years I have never had a recipe go wrong when I used Imperial.  With regards to the salt, I just checked the package and it says that 1 tbsp has only 105mg of sodium.  I followed this recipe exactly and used the full amount of salt and my cookies do not taste salty.  Also, it is interesting that in the recipe for chocolate chip cookies on the back of the Imperial box, there is no salt listed.

I made as is except I added 1 tsp cinnamon and omitted the nuts so i can put them in my son'd daycare lunch box. They do cook flat and at first, i thought they didn't look like most cookies do when the timer went off so i cooked them for a further 2 mins. They still looked a little under done but i took them out anyway as the edges were browning and left to cool for 15 mins before i thought they were solidified enough as they are very soft and chewy.  The end result is a nice chewy consistency and good flavor. I dropped 1 tbsp full scoops and got about 48 cookies. I gave this recipe 4 stars because it does need a few adjustments to make it better. Easy to make too!

Unlike most of the reviewers, I didn't change the amount of flour in the mix (though I did initially change the amount of salt). I subbed mini M&Ms for walnuts and mixed in both mini and regular semi sweet chocolate chips. The first batch I made burned on the bottom and tasted quite flat. I added cinnamon and coffee grounds (to taste) and refrigerated my dough for 2 hours before baking the next round. They came out PERFECT!! The coffee and cinnamon adds depth to the cookies (and there are a LOT of oats that need flavor boosting in this recipe). I would totally make it again keeping with the cinnamon and coffee (and maybe some nutmeg next time!)

Followed the recipe with the following exceptions, added 1 tsp nutmeg powder, 1 tsp cinnamon powder, used organic dark brown sugar instead of light brown, substituted walnuts with pecans and chilled the dough for 30 mins before scooping. text:
I made the first batch without reading other reviewers suggestions so they came out a bit flat and waaay too soft! I quickly added an extra 1/4 c of flour and 1/2 c of quick oats to the remaining dough, baked at 345 for 11 mins, leaving them to rest on the hot cookie sheet for 5 minutes after baking. These adjustments resulted in firm, chewy, perfectly baked cookies. I will definitely reduce the salt by 1/2 next time as I found it to be a bit much. I also omitted the nuts and stuck to chocolate chips only. This one is going in my recipe box!

text:
Hmm I did not see the reviews beforehand and I made this on a whim. 1 TEASPOON of salt has always been too much for cookie batter, so I opted to do a few pinches. I'm glad I did. I wasn't sure about 2 whole cups of oats, so I only did 3. My batter was not runny. The butter was softened, not melted down, so I'm not sure why others were so wet. My cookies are VERY light and after cooling fall apart easily, but I'm not complaining. I did not want mine very thick. I also used a single cup of unsweetened apple sauce to replace the eggs and slightly less white sugar (the applesauce is sweet tasting so not as much sugar is needed). I did not increase my flour. 

If your batter is runny, don't over mix. But also, freezing for 5-10 minutes beforehand thickens the batter. If you freeze overnight, it needs to thaw but if you freeze for a few minutes it's good to go in the oven right away. I like to make a single batch and save the batter in the freezer for another time. 

Overall, I think everyone modifies cookie recipes to their own liking naturally. Some people want their's healthier, sweeter, thicker, thinner, etc. The reviews didn't lead me to modify. I just do that on my own :)  I think it's a great recipe to experiment with to make your own. I will probably do future modifications for fun, not because the recipe is bad. Quite the contrary. These cookies are YUMMY.

text:
This was a great base cookie recipe! We are a GF house so I'm always looking for good basic recipes to convert. 

Just in case anyone else is looking for a tasty GF cookie recipe I will share my conversion notes below.

Notes:
Sub 1 1/4 flour for 1 1/4 fine almond flour. 
Add in  2 TBS flax meal to help it hold together. 
Use and additional 1/2 tsp baking soda for lift.
Scoop a scant TBS per cookie and this will help with spreading and consistency.
Bake for 15-17 min as almond flour has more moisture.

Coincidentally, I was out of chocolate chips so I used raisons and added a pinch of cinnamon.  Next time I will try to use a bit less sugar as they were a touch too sweet fo my taste.

text:
Life long baker and cookie maker here, adding my first note because these came out as the BEST oatmeal cookies I have ever made or tasted. I really wanted to share!I took the advice of some earlier reviews as well as making my own adjustments: -increased flour by ½ cup -increased baking soda by ½ tsp -reduced salt to ½ tsp -removed the walnuts and chocolate chips -added 2/3 cup dried blueberries.   -added 2 bars (1.45oz each) of dark chocolate, hand chopped into chip-size chunks -covered dough and chilled in refrigerator overnight -rolled into ¾ to 1 inch size balls; kept dough balls in refrigerator until ready to bake and between batches -baked 15-18 minutes at 325. Yoda would say: “My new favorite cookies, these are!”

text:
I read a number of the most recent reviews and followed their advice.  I increased flour (1 1/2+ cups), decreased salt to 1/4 tsp, increased baking soda to 1 tsp.  I also creamed the initial ingredients for about 5 minutes and then did not over stir flour mixture. I used dark choc chips, walnuts and added craisins.  I experimented with chilling dough vs. not - found no difference.  Lastly, I cooked at 375 for about 10 min.  Crispy on outside, chewy inside.  Yielded 5 WOWs and 3 Holy Cows from my husband - so I'm keeping this recipe!!

text:
Love this recipe. Even my son who is fussy loved it. I used this recipe and turned it into a gluten free cookies. My daughter can’t have wheat, and  my friends. So used gluten free flour and gluten free rolled oats. You may need to add 1/2 cup more flour, but try and see how moist the dough is first before you add this in. Also I chilled this dough for an hour ( I did it overnight) so that the oatmeal soaks up some of the excess moisture. Check your dough to feel the texture. If you have high humidity it will have an affect on your baking.

text:
New go-to recipe!  About 100x better than standard chocolate chip cookies. Here are my changes based on comments:
1. Increase the flour by 1/2c.
2. Half the salt
3. Half the vanilla
4. Mix-ins: I split the dough in half before the mix-ins and then did 1 cup of cranberries in half and then 1 cup of semi-sweet chocolate chips in the other half. I didn't have nuts but almonds with the cranberries and a little orange zest would be amazing pretty sure.
12min at 350, cooling on the pan is what worked best for me. They were even better after the dough chilled for ~24h.

text:
I made 1 simple change to the recipe that took it from a very good recipe to an amazing recipe! Instead of just 1 cup of walnuts I added about 4 cups, and these turned out to be some of the best cookies I've ever had. I received numerous pleas from everyone to make many more batches. 

I made the cookies rather large, so I did have to alter the cooking temperature and time a bit to somewhere around 300-325 degrees. I got about 9 cookies out of the entire recipe. Also, for forming the cookies I treated them basically like a hamburger patty. I pinched off a large ball of dough; flattened it into a patty; and then used the inside of my thumb and forefinger around the outer edge to even it out.

Lastly, I just wanted to mention that the few people who had difficulty with this recipe... I'm sorry, but they just can't cook. The recipe is fine, and the cookies are delicious.

text:
The taste of these cookies is awesome and they do not contain extravagant amounts of sugar.
I followed the recipe exactly, except I used spelt flour instead of white flour, which really does not make a big difference.
My cookies were not flat at all, as other reviewers had complained.
I think the trick is in the MAKING, not the INGREDIENTS.
You should thoroughly whisk the wet ingredients for a good amount of time, until they become fluffy. Make sure you give it a good whisk between each egg.
When you add the last part (oats, choc chips, etc) CHURN them in lightly until just mixed well enough, don't overdo it.

text:
The only change I made was instead of butter, I used lard that I rendered myself.  The flavor is a bit different, but I enjoy it. 

Regarding the cookies spreading out too thin, I did not have that problem. Mine puffed up a bit too much, so I just flattened them a bit with the spatula when they came out of the oven, then let them sit on the cookie sheet for 5 minutes, as the recipe states. To keep cookies from spreading too thin, I reserve 1/4 to 1/2 of the flour, and add that as the very last ingredient, working it in with my hands. Another mistake I've made regarding this is I have reflexively greased the cookie sheet, without noticing the recipe said UNgreased.

text:
I've baked two batches of chocolate-chip cookies a while ago. It was delicious! I have made baking or no-baking required cookies previously. This was definitely the best of them. No more buying chocolate-chip cookies from stores for me. As I often do, I have customized this recipe, too. I used 1 and 1/2 cups of generic brand of old fashioned oats flour which I made in my Vitamix in 30 seconds instead of using all purpose flour. I have used a tbsp of ground flaxseeds and a tsp of nutritional yeast, and a cup of oats with 1/2 cup of ON Whey Protein powder to have less guilt. I work out regularly and I do crave for sugar from time to time particularly when I am having a cup of coffee or tea. Also, I swapped white sugar with 9 packets of sweet n'low (1/2 cup of white sugar is equal to 12 packets of SnL) though I intentionally used less since I find chocolate-chip cookies sold in stores too sweet. I have also used 1 tsp of almond extract and about 2 ounces of 72% dark chocolate (I used a mortal&pestle after I crushed it by hand) since I did not have chocolate chips or vanilla extract at home at the time. Based on my previous experience, I think I will continue using dark chocolate instead of chocolate chips. The result is much better. I kept it 15 minutes in the oven. Both batches of 19 pieces of large cookies came out great, a little soft, chewy but crispy -crunchy and not flat. Though, I'd like to say that I'll reduce the amount of salt next time by a qtr of a teaspoon at least.

text:
These are great cookies, the best I made. I followed the helpful previous advices and changed for a bit HEALTHIER version. So the overall changes are:
Flour: replaced with whole wheat and used 1.5 cup
1 tea spon baking soda
1/2 tea spoon salt
Sugar: used only 1 cup packed dark brown sugar, omitted the 1/2 cup white 
Added cinamon
Froze the dough 10 minutes beforw baking
Baked 12 minutes at 335 and let it cool on the baking pan

The result is very tasty,  chewy and mildly sweet cookis that my family LOVED

Thank you for a great recipe!

text:
These are very good cookies, when a few modifications are made. 

At the advice of previous reviews I: cut the salt in half, doubled the baking soda, added 1/2 cup of flour. 

I also: added a full tbsp of vanilla (vs the 2/3 tbsp in the recipe), cut the walnuts to 3/4 a cup, added 3/4 cup of chopped dried cherries, added 1/2 tsp cinnamon.

I almost always refrigerate cookie dough before baking, but this dough held up fine when I baked it right away.

text:
I made only two small changes - I used half margarine and half butter instead of all butter, as I always do this when I make chocolate chip cookies, it's just a personal preference.  I also cream the butter and sugars very well, until its light and fluffy.  The other change is I baked them at 340 degrees.  325 just seemed too low.  I think next time I'll try 350  as that's the temp I usually use for these kind of cookies.  At 340 degrees, they baked up to lovely chewy perfection with nice light brown bottoms in 16 minutes in my propane gas oven (we live kind of in the middle of nowhere boondocks,  so we have propane).   I used the quick cooking oats.   These cookies were so darn good!  My husband and I really enjoyed them so much.  They were moist, chewy and had just the right sweetness.  Thanks for sharing the recipe, it's a keeper!

Did my Christmas baking today; I did as other Reviewers suggested, upped the flour by 1/2C and the baking soda by 1/2 tsp, creamed/beat the butter and sugars longer than suggested and mixed the dry ingredients by hand. I used a cookie scoop to drop them onto nonstick foil lined pans and baked until lightly browned. Daughter doesn't care for raisins or nuts, so I used Ghirardelli's semi sweet chocolate chips. As you can see, the cookies are in various stages of light brown deliciousness. Daughter ate one still warm from the oven and said they're very good; that's big coming from a teen who doesn't care for oatmeal cookies! Thank you for sharing. This is my go to recipe for oatmeal cookies.

text:
This is my absolute favorite cookie recipe, I've been making it for years! 

I do change it up a TINY bit though to make it perfect:
1. I nix the walnuts and just add extra chocolate chips (white chocolate, dark chocolate, semi-sweet mmmm)
2. I use course salt, this adds an amazing salty sweet taste.
3. I ALWAYS refrigerate or even freeze the dough before cooking, for at least an hour. This ensures they don't flatten out too much.

I've gotten so many compliments on these cookies, they have an amazing, unique flavor and the texture is amazing, chewy and delicious.

Rewriting my review since I hit Enter before finishing... These are delicious!  I made them with only two changes. 1) Subbed more chocolate chips for the walnuts. We just don't care for the nuts in most cookies. 2) I greased my cookie sheets because I didn't trust my sheets. Lol  I'm not sure why some had their cookies go flat, or their dough was too wet. My lighter ones were in 13 minutes, cooled a bit longer than five on the sheet.  The darker were 14 minutes with almost no cooling time. Both are yummy but 13 minutes worked best for my preference.

text:
After reading most all of the comments, I made this cookie recipe with: 1 cup salted butter, 1 cup brown sugar, 1/2 cup white sugar, 1-1/2 cup flour, 1 tsp. baking soda, 1/2 tsp. salt, 3 tsp. vanilla extract, no nuts, 12 oz. pkg. semi-sweet chocolate chips and 2-1/2 cups quick cook oats.

The mixture was a bit dry which is why I put only 2-1/2 cup instead of 3 cups of oats.  I put the mixture in the freezer for about 10 minutes.  I lined my cookie sheets with parchment paper.  I scooped out the dough using a small cookie scoop (similar to an ice cream scoop), I pressed each cookie dough lightly before baking.  

After many people were complaining of the cookie dough running together while baking, I thought it best to freeze for a bit, after the first batch it was unnecessary.  Matter of fact, had I not pressed the dough down slightly they might not have spread out much.

The cookies were moist & chewy, great tasting!  I only gave it 4 stars because I had to make a few modifications.

text:
This is a GREAT recipe! I use sweet cream, unsalted butter and it gives them that gourmet flavor! I did have to make some adjustments. I use 2 1/2 c flour, 1 tsp baking soda and only 1/4 tsp salt. I also use 1 1/2 c dark chocolate chips! I have not had a problem with flat cookies! I spread the dough in a 9x13 pan and cook for approximately 30 min. It makes about 3 dozen cookies (with one or two left over for the baker!) Also, it is a forgiving recipe! I misread the amounts of brown and white sugar so ended up adding 1/2 c too much! They turned out fine!

text:
Ok this recipe will create a monster. It's SO delicious (and I added PEANUT BUTTER!!) Followed the previous recs of +1/2c flour, + 1/2t baking soda, and -1/2t salt and HIGHLY recommend doing the same. Also, I know it's satisfying to beat ingredients until uber smooth, but just don't do that when you beat in the eggs. Add 1, beat it for about 5-8 seconds, add the next and repeat. After setting the mixer aside, this is where I added in the PB... When you add vanilla, take about 2T PB (I used creamy but crunchy would be fun/tasty) and just GENTLY stir it on in until it is combined with the rest. When you mix in the flour, salt and baking soda mixture, just nicely mix it in. Don't look for the white to disappear. Of course I was generous with my oat and choc chip measurements, but who's counting? I baked these bad boys on parchment paper (after consuming about 1 cookie's worth of dough- oops!!) and they cooked evenly/ clean up was a sinch. I've made these cookies 3x and have cooked them about 13 mins each time. Maybe my oven doesn't get as hot, unsure about that but just use your baker's common sense!

text:
I read a lot of the reviews and decided to go with adding the little extra flour, baking soda & less salt. Here's what I did...all the other ingredients I kept the same measurement. I used 1 3/4 c. of flour, 1 tsp baking soda & 1/4 tsp salt. I also added 1 tsp cinnamon and 1/4 tsp all spice. I creamed the butter and sugars just until combined (not light and fluffy). I followed the directions on combining the rest of the ingredients. The oven at 325, I scooped out portions with a cookie scoop, placed on parchment paper lined baking sheets and placed in fridge for about 1/2 hr. I baked for 12-13 min. The cookies didn't flatten out or spread to much, they weren't gooey on the inside, they were firm on the outside and good texture on the inside. I use steel cut oats for my cookies. The flavor was balanced with the sweetness and the spices I used. In my baking I usually bring my eggs and butter to room temp, but this time I took the butter out of the fridge and microwaved for about 10 seconds to just soften it. If the butter is too soft, then the cookies will spread. I like this recipe and will keep the changes I made. I hope this helps everyone!

text:
I followed the recipe and my only addition was a half-teaspoon corn starch (something I add to all my cookies to help them puff up nicely); otherwise, I made no changes and I used a large cookie dough scoop and had 14 dough balls which I chilled in the fridge for 2 hours. I baked them for 10 minutes on two sheets with parchment paper on them, let them cool 10 minutes and transferred to cooling racks. They were still slightly gooey in the centers when removed from the oven. You DO NOT WANT these cookies over baked. I cannot stress this enough or you will have hard cookies when cooled. The cookies stayed puffed up, were tender and gooey in the centers but just slightly crisped around the edges. My granddaughters and their friends said they were the best ever!  Will definitely use this again. Yes, there are changes I can do to make it more healthy for my husband and I but made as written - they are just perfect the way that they are.  I will add that putting the mounds of cookie dough (not the bowl of dough) in the fridge for at least two hours will guarantee the nice thick puffy cookie that we all desire and not a flat one when cooled. Be sure to let them cool on the pan as advised so that they hold together when transferred to a cooling rack. Love these!  YUM!!!

text:
These cookies turned out amazing, but I can't give it 5 stars because I made several modifications: I used half unsalted butter and half shortening. I increased the flour to 1-1/2 cups (most reviews say to use 1-3/4, so I'm not sure if that would have made them turn out even better), increased the baking soda to 1 tsp, and decreased the salt to 1/2 tsp. I also left out the walnuts and added extra chocolate chips. I then chilled  the batter in the freezer for about an hour. Since the dough was hard, I rolled them into balls instead of dropping by the spoonful, which just made them come out more round. I baked them at 350 degrees for 12-13 minutes.

I discovered this trick by accident. Add the oats-chips-nuts to the wet mixture before the flour mixture and mix with your hands. This  prevents your cookies from flattening in the oven.. I don't know how or why it works, it just does. Your cookies will come out of the oven the same shape they went in with. I used half salted butter and half vegetable shortening and chilled the dough for 45 min.

text:
1st batch- very sweet, flavorful 
2nd batch- lightly sweet + milk 1/4 c + flour 1/4 c for structure and consistency 


*15 mins is plenty of cooking time for light browning- I gloss the cooking sheet with vegetable oil to allow the cookies to come off the cooking sheet a little more easier. 

*The salt takes away from the sweetness, definitely a good contrast to the flavors. Cranberries would be a great way to suit this contrast as well. 

These cookies were very flavorful and fluffy. I made sure to only mix the ingredients enough to absorb the dry ingredients. First, separating the dry and wet ingredients. Then, mixing the dry ingredients  before adding the wet ingredients. I also found it helpful to add about a 1/4 cup milk to make the cookies more moist. I leveled that mixture with flour to get the  right consistency that I desired. In the second batch, I eased up on the sugar and only used brown sugar to flavor the cookies. I also placed the cookie dough into the fridge for the dough to become more solid.

* I think its very important not to over mix the dough as this can cause the cookies to lose structure during the cooking process and even become flat.

text:
This is the second time I made this recipe. We are chewy cookie connoisseurs! Changed a couple of things. Melt the butter! Liquify it. Add the sugar and mix the tar out of it. Set in fridge for 5 min while you mix the dry ingredients together. Take out the wet mix and add the eggs, vanilla, and 1 tbsp of maple syrup. Mix the tar out of it again. Add your flour mixture. Tar mix. It should be slightly runny. Fold in the oats. I added a whole bag of milk chocolate chips and did not add any walnuts. Chill in fridge for 10-15 . Tbsp drop these lovelies onto the sheet. I get 8 per standard sheet.  Put that mix back in fridge. Cook for 12 min exactly.  Cool for 5 min on sheet. Transfer to cooling rack. They are extra chewy and my husband ate 30 cookies in less than a day. They go fast.

Good recipe. This cookie baked thin and just chewy enough with a little crisp on the edges - and is tasty.  I use salted butter, so used only 1/2 tsp salt.  Knowing the amount of brown sugar and butter used will help the cookies spread quite a bit, I baked 6 at a time on the cookie sheet - using a heaping kitchen tablespoon size. I would use this cookie recipe again for cookie sandwiches, but not if I needed a bulk of cookies for casual eating munching. Thanks!

I ended up cooking them for a 2 minutes longer (14 minutes) in an oven that was 160 degrees rather than 165 as I was concerned about the bottoms and edges browning too much. The only thing I did to change the recipe was add more chocolate and I substituted the cup of walnuts for a cup of raw peanuts instead. The cookies turned out great.

text:
I read many reviews on this recipe before trying, however I felt that I should follow the actual recipe first to leave a ligit review. The only part of the recipe I changed was I omitted the nuts, because I didn't have any. The first cookie batch came out very flat and at 325 degrees for 12 minutes, underbaked. As the first batch cooked I put the remaining dough into the freezer to chill. The second batch I increased the heat to 335 degrees (per a previous reviewer's suggestion) and cooked for 12 minutes. they were a tiny bit better but not much. The cookies although flat did taste really good warm from the oven but would not last over 30 minutes before becoming very, very crunchy. My verdict is 3 stars as written. I would not serve these to anyone without adjustments.

As previous reviewer's suggested I will increase the flour, and the baking soda as well as chill the dough. With the changes the results are fabulous and worth 5 stars!

text:
I followed this recipe almost to the exact. The only thing I didn't do was add a teaspoon of salt. I never add the amount of salt a recipe calls for. I just sprinkled in a little. Mixed the wet ingredients with a hand mixer and then mixed in the dry ingredients to that with a mixer. The oatmeal, chocolate chips and walnuts I mixed in by hand. The recipe says to drop by spoonfuls but I rolled them into balls and then flattened them out a bit. I also cooked for 15 minutes instead of twelve. They did not come out flat. They were absolutely delicious. I'm not normally an oatmeal cookie lover but I am embarrassed to admit I ate five of these almost immediately after baking. I was so pleased With this recipe I even took some down to my neighbor. This is most definitely a keeper recipe for me.

text:
Came out perfect!  I looked at reviews and changed these ingredients: 2 cups flour, 1 tsp baking soda, no salt, 1 tsp vanilla, some cinnamon, 2 1/2 cups old fashioned  oatmeal.  Put the batter in the fridge for a bit and in between cookies baking. Scooped batter with mini ice cream scooper.   If the batter was colder 12 minute bake time is best.  Next time I will let the butter soften at room temperature and not let it melt.  Then I will experiment with how much flour I will need.  This time the butter melted and might be why I needed so much more flour.  I also used a 1/4 teaspoon cream of tartar.

text:
These cookies are not too bad. I followed the recipe exact. As others stated, they are too salty. I suggest only adding 1/2 tsp of salt. My cookies did not turn out flat, bc I made sure to soften my butter at room temperature (not microwave). Also, I freeze my dough while letting the oven preheat.  I also suggest cooking at 350 degrees for 14 minutes then leave them on pan for 5 minutes as recipe suggests. My second and third pan turned out better by longer cooking time. Hope this helps.

Delicious! Could use a tad less salt if you are sensitive, but otherwise these are fantastic.  I made them exactly the recipe suggest. I'll admit, I was a little nervous after reading some of reviews saying that the recipe needed more oats. I feared the cookies wouldn't turn out well because the dough did seem a little loose.  However, I went ahead and popped the first batch into the oven to bake. Then my nervousness took over and added more oats to the 2nd half of the dough. I needed the cookies for a party at my daughters school and really needed them to turn out.  After the first batch (exactly as written) was finished, I baked the second batch (with a little more oats). Then I did a taste test with my family and EVERYONE, (including me) preferred the cookies made exactly as the recipe is written.  Took off one star for the slight saltiness of this recipe, but these cookies are super delicious anyway.

text:
Not sure why there are negative reviews. If your cookies are flat it's because you've over mixed the dough. Stand mixers are notorious for over mixing. I use my hand held mixer for cookies to avoid this problem. Additionally, if you chill your dough for at least half an hour or until it is firm, you'll get a more compact cookie. I used a hand mixer and did not chill the dough and mine came out perfect. I used the small dough scoop from BB&B and it made four dozen perfect. I think you get more compact cookies when you use a scoop instead of a spoon. My family loved the cookies. I might cut out some of the salt next time. I did not add nuts due to my son's braces. Next time I might try adding half chocolate chip and half butterscotch chips. Great recipe!

Sooooo I see a lot of people stating their cookies ended up flat ----> reasoning behind it is either you greased the baking sheet or cooked them on a stick free pan or you live at a crazy altitude.  These cookies need high friction on the bottom so they don't collapse and fall flat so cook them on a regular cookie sheet without oil/butter.  Flavoring wise they are ok but missing cinnamon .... text:
These cookies are amazing!!!!  I usually cut the sugar in all baked goods and this one was no different.  It does not need the entire amount of sugar.  Also, I used half white whole wheat flour and it is undetectable.  The best tip I have for cookies though is to refrigerate the dough for 24 hours AFTER mixing and BEFORE baking.  The next day I pull the dough out of the fridge and let it sit on the counter until it softens up a bit. I know it is hard to wait, usually one bakes cookies when a craving has struck:)  However, try it once and you will be a convert!  The cookies flavor intensify and deepen making a truly superb treat!

text:
These were definitely edible, though I expected more after the great reviews.  My brother even commented that they tasted like 'diet cookies'.  I will add less oats next time (maybe 1.5-2 cups) since I think that made them dry tasting and less sweet.  I had no problem with the shape, but did let the dough chill for about 2 hours and added more flour and baking soda, as others suggested.  I didn't cut the salt because I used unsalted butter.  Because they didn't flatten much, I had to cook them much longer (close to 20 minutes) and used wax paper.  I tried all the different cooking variations as another reviewer did, but none of them were long enough.  The tops and bottoms were a perfect color and never browned, so it was hard to gauge when I should take them out.  I don't mind a 'doughy' center, so I'm trying a batch now on lesser time.

text:
I have made these gluten-free dairy-free nut-free and low sugar.

Here is my variations
Replace butter with ½ cup ghee and ½ cup applesauce. Replace white and brown sugar with 3/4 cup Turbinado sugar or sugar in the raw. I have used as little as 1/2 cup and they still taste good. I have replaced the wheat flour with oat flour before to make a gluten-free cookie and they turned out great. Rice flour did not work very well. I used 1 teaspoon baking soda & ½ teaspoon salt plus 1 teaspoon cinnamon. I always add an additional 1/2 oats. I like to use 1 cup chopped pecans instead of walnuts but I have also left the nuts out entirely  and  I have also substituted sunflower seeds. I prefer to make my cookies dairy-free by using 1 cup raisins instead of using chocolate.

I also baked at 375 degree F for 15 minutes

text:
Pretty good. I did modify the recipe a bit, based off my own experience and other's reviews. I use unsalted butter so I left the salt as is. Used 1/4 cup more flour, added an extra 1/2 tsp baking soda, a dash of cinnamon, no nuts, and more chocolate chips (milk chocolate). I refrigerated the dough for about an hour.(I have 2 toddlers and a 6 month old baby. I have to do things in stages.) Baked at 325 for about 13 minutes for my oven. Turned out not too puffy, not too flat with the perfect crispy edges and chewy center. I will make these again. Hope this helps. :)

text:
Awesome with following changes SO EASY! Mixed all in Kitchenaid SO QUICK! I used 1 3/4 cup flour and 1 tsp baking soda. First batch only 1/2 cup butter NO SPREADING 2nd batch (used white chocolate chips and cranberries) used full cup of butter and the cookies spread so if you want cookies to spread use full cup butter if prefer thicker cookie use 1/2 cup.  In both cases place dough in fridge for minimum 45 minutes for easier handling. I then just used my 2" cookie scoop! You have to try white chocolate and cranberry I dont even like cranberries and I couldn't stop eating these. NOTE*** Soak craisins in hot water for 10 minutes dry off with paper towel before adding to dough. Enjoy!

text:
I followed this recipe to a "T" and didnt have any problems with cookies flattening out.  What I did was (using a electric mixer) mix sugars and butter and then mix in the eggs and vanilla.  Still using the electric mixer, I added the flour mixture slowly into the wet.  Then mixed by hand the chips, oatmeal and walnuts. I did not use a spoon to put cookies onto sheet.  I used my hands to form balls about 1 1/2".  A little sticky granted, but once you have the right amount, wash your hands and the water will make it easier to form the balls correctly.  The cookies were left on the cookie sheet lined with parchment paper for about 10 mins.  Also, because these were ball shaped, the cookies dont have dark or crispy edges, they simply have a beautiful golden colour all over, and bake throughout evenly.

text:
This is a great basic recipe. After reading the reviews, I cut the salt by 1/4 teaspoon, added 1/4 cup flour, used butter-flavored shortening so the cookies wouldn't spread too much and become flat, used 1 teaspoon each of baking soda and baking powder. I used 2 1/2 cups quick cooking oats instead of 3 cups because I was afraid the dough would be too thick with the shortening and the extra nuts and chocolate chips I like to add. These cookies came out perfectly chewy with just the right amount of crunch on the edge. They stayed soft even after they cooled. I will be adding this one to my go-to recipe box.

I was looking for a kind of healthy cookie and these turned out to be a great option! I made a few changes: substitute coconut oil for the butter, used only brown sugar (1 1/3 c), a little more flour (1.5 c), doubled the baking soda (1 tsp) and reduced the salt (1/4 tsp).  I used natural rolled oats (not the quick cooking ones) and liked them a lot! On the first batch I forgot the chocolate chips and we really liked them, so maybe sometimes I will leave those out on purpose.  Oh, and half of the recipe made 16 cookies, Thanks for the recipe!

text:
These cookies were good.  I took the advice of others and increased the four 1/2 cup, baking soda 1/2 tsp, and used no salt since I used salted butter.  I also used pecans instead of walnuts.  I put the dough in the freezer for 10 min. I baked them on pampered chef baking stones.  I heated the stones before putting the cookie dough on them.  I baked at 335 for 12 min then let them sit on the stone for 5 min before moving them to a cooling rack.  These cookies did not spread at all with the above modifications.  I had to flatten them down about half way through the baking time.  The taste is good.  I wouldn't say they are fantastic, but I will make them again.

text:
Terrific cookies! Easy to fix, I made a few minor changes...as others suggested I upped the baking soda to 1 tsp., flour to 1 1/2 cups and I also used 1/2 and 1/2 white and whole wheat flour (just to get a little whole grain) and to get my uber-picky 8 year old daughter to be more likely to try them, I increased the chocolate bits to 1 1/2 cups. I really think they would have turned out fine with the original amount of flour though. I think if you follow the recipe directions closely they should turn out as expected. I wonder if some of those that had problems didn't cream the butter and sugars well enough?...I even accidentally put the salt in with the butter-sugar mixture and it didn't hurt a thing. Oh, couple of tips...keep dough heaped up on pan, don't flatten it out any, and do NOT over-bake! The cookies will set up after taking out of the oven. 12 minutes worked for me. My daughter is one of the pickiest eaters this side of the Mississippi River and she ate 4 at one time, and would have had more if I'd let her! My husband raved as well. I think this one is a keeper! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This was a pretty good base, but I had to change a few things. I reduced the salt to 1/2 tsp, and I added 1/2 tsp of cinnamon and 1/4 tsp nutmeg, (they had no flavor otherwise). I also added 1 cup of raisins and omitted the chocolate chips and the nuts, (only because I was out)! They did come out chewy and yummy, but you have to really watch the cooking time, cuz even slightly over-cooked and you'll have a hard cookie on you hands. Also, if they're coming out flat, it may be due to over-mixing. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Used 1 3/4 cup flour, 1 tsp baking soda, and 1/2 tsp salt (used salted butter).  Also reduced oats to 2 cups (because I ran out).  Turned out AWESOME!!!!!   Cookie is halfway between a chocolate chip cookie and an oatmeal cookie, rather than being an oatmeal cookie with chocolate chips.  Tried baking on a baking stone that wasn't preheated - didn't work at all.  Cookies spread out a lot.  Used a light colored pan (not a dark non-stick pan) and the cookies turned out wonderfully after about 11 minutes at about 325°, or maybe a little over that temp (but who knows how accurate my oven is).  Tried chilling the dough, but that only seems to make the baking time take longer.  Turns out just as good without chilling the dough.  Five star rating if you make it my way, no idea if you make it as originally recipe calls for.

I used 1 1/2 C of Brown sugar no white sugar, 1 1/2 C flour, 2 C oats, 1 tsp baking soda, 1 tsp of vanilla, 1 egg, a dash of salt, unsalted butter. I changed this recipe quite a bit got great cookies I like the brown sugar better since I didn't use white sugar I only used 1 tsp of vanilla. I think anymore oats would have made these way to crispy I like my cookies chewy they baked up great, a  crisp edge chewy inside and done inside. Baked at 350 for 10-12 min. my oven bakes hot. I only gave 3 stars since I changed this recipe up so much. I added not quite a cup of chocolate chips no nuts I can't have nuts. Anymore than 3/4 C choc. chips would have been too much. the cookies have plenty of chocolate chips throughout. Great starting point recipe I've lost my go to recipe for oatmeal cookies this with all my changes is now my new one. Play with it and make it your own. Oh also my cookies didn't flatten and I didn't have to put the mix in the fridge it's very cold in OH my kitchen is cool. The recipe without changes I'd call Oatmeal Crisp Cookies since I think they would be very crispy and flatter. Just my opinion I've made oatmeal crisps this sounds very much like that recipe. I made all my changes from reading all the other comments thanks everyone.

Okay so aside from having to alter the recipe they weren't to bad. I put 1 3/4c flour rather than 1 1/4c, also I put 1 teaspoon of baking soda rather than 1/2 and I left out the salt and nuts. rather than dropping them I rolled them into (rather large) balls and baked them for 14mins rather than 12 to adjust for the the size (I like my cookies big and puffy rather than small and flat). They turned out not to bad, the outside was crunchy, not from being over cooked but from the way the recipe is I suppose. the inside was still nice and chewy but that might change after they cool completely. If I use this recipe again I will be using less chocolate chips as I found there were just way to many in this recipe after they were baked.

I can't give 5 stars to this receipe since I altered it quite a bit as suggested by other users. I increased the flour to 1.5 cups, reduced salt to 1/2 tsp. and to cut some of the fat, replaced 1/4 cup of the butter with applesauce. I also used old fashioned oats which probably was the biggest alteration. I cooled the dough for 10 mins in the fridge before I baked and then rolled it into balls before baking. I didn't have any trouble with flattening, in fact, I wish they were flatter! I also split the batch into half choc. chip/walnut and the other was cranberry/orange (added clementine zest). Good but not my forever recipe.

text:
Maybe I'm the only one, but thru trial and error over the years, I found the way to keep the cookies (all cookies) full and not flat, is to use almost cold butter. Yes it takes longer to mix the sugar in, but well worth it. If you use butter that is too room temp, the butter is runny, and when you put it in the oven, it liquifies almost. Chunky semi-cold butter works great! Hope this helps some who want to test it.

Cookies turned out perfect!  They are the best cookies I've ever made!  I used the tips in the reviews of adding 1/2 c. more flour, 1/2 tsp more baking soda & half the amount of salt.  Creamed butter & sugar together until fluffy, then added eggs & vanilla.  I sifted the dry ingredients into the mixture & stirred until just incorporated, then folded in chocolate chips, walnuts and oats.  I made rather large cookies & cooked for approx. 16 minutes.  They are soft, chewy & delicious!!!!!

text:
Very good; the changes mentioned by others are necessary: add 1/2 c flour (although if you scoop flour from the container the amt in the recipe will probably be right.  Scooping packs flour and you end up with more.  If you stir flour and spoon into the measuring cup you will have to add the 1/2 cup.)  Use 1 tsp soda and only 1/2 tsp salt if using salted butter.  I found that these brown faster on a cookie sheet lined with parchment than on a silpat mat; let stand 5 min after baking on silpat, only 2 to 2.5 minutes on parchment.
This is a very good basic chewy oatmeal cookie and can be varied with any kind of chips, nuts, or dried fruit.

I just baked these cookies and I have to say they are very good.  I don't really understand why all the changes with flour, salt, soda etc...  I followed the recipe and it has worked perfect.  You want your butter cold and just starting to soften.  I used regular rolled oats which may have made a difference in the runnyness some had problems with.  As far as the bland complaint, it is an oatmeal cookie so it is more of a wholesome nutty flavor.  I do not like cinnamon in my chocolate and nothing worse than biting into an oatmeal cookie that has what you think is chocolate chips to find it's actually raisins.  That being said, you could add more vanilla and even cherries would be great.  Anything to your taste actually.  Great basic oatmeal cookie recipe.  Thank you for posting it.

text:
These were pretty good. I halved the recipe, omitted the walnuts and salt, used Smart Balance instead of butter, and added 1/2 a mashed banana. I added a bit more flour and baking soda as per the reviews, but the dough seemed a bit dry and needed to add a tiny bit of (soy) milk to make it more balanced. I had no problems with spreading and baked them a bit longer than suggested since I made large cookies. Actually my favorite part of the recipe is the hint of banana that I added- it's a really nice touch. In fact, I wouldn't make these without the added banana. Overall, I enjoyed them and would make them again.

These came out delicious...I made a few changes and I'm glad that I did.  I didnt want 42 cookies so I decreased the recipe down to 21 cookies and the measurements were spot on.  I used dark brown sugar instead of light brown sugar and I used roasted, salted almonds instead of walnuts.  I crushed the almonds in a plastic bag using a meat mallet.  Finally, instead of butter I used a crisco butter flavored baking stick and for chocolate I used a Russell Stover chocolate bunny left from easter that I cut up into chunks.  The batter seemed dry but I went with it and shaped the cookies into balls and then placed them on the cookie sheet to bake...they were PERFECT!!!

Thanks for such sharing such a delicious recipe, definately worth keeping, my family loves it, and great for beginners!

These are my absolute favorite cookies, and everyone who eats them loves them as well!  They are a perfect chewy cookie!  It is also really easy to make a smaller batch if you don't want the 42 the recipe calls for.  The only thing I changed was to double the vanilla.  **DO NOT OVERMIX -- a lot of people mix forever and their cookies turn out bad.  **DO NOT OVERBAKE -- they should still be soft on the cookie sheet when they come out of the oven -- let them cool a few minutes on the sheet then transfer to wire racks to finish.

text:
I almost cringed when I read 'a good basic cookie' in the reviews. This cookie is so complex and delicious I found that rather offensive. I followed the recipe to a T (with the exception of replacing a small part of the chocolate and walnuts with sultana raisins) and they came out pretty much the best cookies I had ever had. 

They are sweet, with a hint of saltiness, chewy oatmealy goodness, complex walnut flavor and rich chocolate chunks. I did leave them in the oven for an extra 3 minutes (the temperature was running a little low though). I was tempted to put them in even longer because they weren't exactly crispy but I read in the reviews that they keep on baking even after being removed from the oven and my gosh, after they'd cooled down they were perfectly crunchy on the outside and wonderfully chewy on the inside. Love them!

text:
Pretty good recipe.  I didn't have any problems with flat cookies.  Mine were not big and puffy  like in some of the pictures either, they looked like cookies from a gourmet shop.  I did change the recipe a little to add some whole wheat flour (don't worry, they still taste good).  I did 1 cup all-purpose flour, 3/4 cup whole wheat flour, 1 tsp baking soda & 1/2 tsp salt.  I brought my eggs to room tempurature before adding in and used an ice cream scoop to scoop cookie dough (I like them big).  Only put 5 cookies to a sheet.  Flatten just a little with hand then add a few more chocolate chips on top for aesthetics.  I baked in a 345 degree convection oven for 10 minutes, switching shelves halfway through.  Cookies came out very pretty.  As long as your pans are not already hot when you put the dough on them the cookies should not spread at all.

These are the most amazing things i've ever made!  So easy and delicious, i'm making them right now for the second time in three days.  I took advice from a few other posts, I added more flour and baking soda, I mixed the butter and sugars for awhile until very light and fluffy and hand mixed the rest. Then baked on 335 for around 13 minutes watching very closely.  PERFECT!  Just barley brown on the bottom, moist and chewy in the middle and the oats make it very hearty.  I think the amount of salt is perfect, I love the mix of saltiness with chocolate (which i added a little extra).  The walnuts give it a great crunch and flavor. I had to pat them into more disk shapes rather than balls as they held their shape and didn't flatten out at all.  Thank you so much Panthera and to the others for posting your tips!

Four and a half stars because my husband really liked them - but I had to make a few changes. Firstly - did no one think that three cups of quick oats was overkill? I used half that amount and it was still plenty "oaty." I did increase the flour to 1 3/4 cups, and increased the baking soda to one tsp. I added 1/2 cup of white chocolate chips in addition to the 2 cups of semi-sweet. Took one reviewer's advice and baked at 335 degrees for 12 minutes and they came out perfect: chewy and soft with crisp edges and golden bottoms.

text:
Ok, heres review #1,817...OMG, like this needs another one? Anyway, I read a quite a few reviews and here's what I did a bit differently. 1/2 C each butter & shortening, 1 C brn sugar only, 1/2 AP and 1/2 whole wheat flour, only used 2-1/2 cups quick cooking oats (ground up 1/2 C of it). 1/2 tsp salt & 1 tsp baking soda. Used same amount of nuts and ch chips (Hersheys). I also added 1/3 C of rehydrated dried cherries, roughly chopped. My batter was pretty dry (probably due to using wheat flour). Dough sat in the frige overnight (w/clear wrap pressed on top) due to starting late in the evening. I let the dough come back to room temp next morning and had to add a tblsp of water as it was still pretty dry. Anyway, did the 335 degree oven and because I made my cookies bigger (size of golf ball, pressed down some) I cooked for 15 minutes or until edges just started to brown. They turned out exactly like I wanted - moist, tender, chewy and not sick sweet. Oh, I did add 1 tsp cinnamon & 1/2 t ea nutmeg, grnd coriander and allspice. Don't know how well they will keep as I just baked these today. Update: cookies were just as good 4 days later.

These are excellent! The funny thing is that I wanted flat, crisp cookies which is what I expected after reading the complaining reviews that these went flat in the oven.  But mine didn't go flat at all, they barely spread!  I used an ice cream scoop to portion, baked on parchment at 335 (as another review suggested) for 12 minutes and they were perfect.  They were puffy and undercooked looking when I took them out, but once they cooled on the cookie sheet they fell and were perfectly chewy in the middle and barely crisp at the edges.

I made my first batch of these cookies about 30 minutes ago and they are pretty awesome! The only things that I did alter were the baking time and the flour. I upped the baking time to 15-17 min - I wanted the cookies a bit firmer since I have so many to bake don't want to wait 5 minutes for them to cool and helps them to really brown. I also used rice flour in lieu of the all-purpose and the taste is great :-) None of these cookies are flat (unlike the unfortunate experiences of others) and I don't know why that would be but maybe my modifications will help someone else.

text:
A fabulous cookie! I did as others suggested, increased the flour and baking soda and decreased the salt. I also added raisins as I had no walnuts. It's important not to mix the dough too much, just until a ball sticks together in your hand. I rolled them into balls and flattened each one slightly, and they didn't spread at all; also, it's important to leave them on the pan for 5 minutes after they come out of the oven, as the recipe suggests, otherwise they do fall apart. So be patient! It is so totally worth it!

text:
Great, great great! I'll never make plain chocolate chip cookies again.   My tips: Do as the other reviews said and up the flour and baking soda and used less salt. And I always use an extra splash of vanilla. When making these, I accidentally, I ran out of time 1/2 way thru baking these, so I put the 2nd 1/2 in the fridge. The next day I took it out to bake. The dough was a little crumbly, but I wet my hands and then pushed the dough together in my palm. These cookies were noticeably better than the 1st half. So if you have time, refridgerate! They're great either way though.

text:
This recipe is really, really yummy if adjusted.  I gleaned the information from a previous poster, and added a few twists of my own.  The adjustments to the original recipe is as follows:  I used 1 egg, and 2 egg whites instead of 2 eggs  I used 1/2 cup of apple sauce, and 1/2 cup of butter instead of 2 sticks of butter  I used 1 teaspoon of baking soda instead of a half of a teaspoon  I used 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour and 3/4 cup of white flour instead of 1 and 1/4 cups of white flour  I used 1/2 cup of splenda instead of 1/2 cup of sugar  I added 1/4 cup of extra oats, and I used Old Fashioned Oats  Finally, I used a combination of semi-sweet and milk choc. chips...However, next time I'm going to use 1/2 crushed dark chocolate, and 1/2 semi-sweet....  Also, I think raisens would be awesome instead of chocolate chips!  I know there are alot of edits, but they sure came out excellent!!!

text:
Tasty, but there is an issue with spreading, as mentioned in many of the other reviews. I tried refrigerating the dough, but that hardly helps the cause. You will have to make adjustments. This recipe is actually nearly identical to the recipe that comes on the underside lid of the Quaker Oats canister. The only difference, but clearly an important one, is the amount of flour that is added to the mixture. The result is a well-formed cookie. A touch too crisp on the edges for my taste, so I developed a technique that helps keep softness uniformly throughout the cookie.  My preference is to turn off the oven ever so slightly on the early side. I open the oven door to let the hot air out, then shut the door and let the residual heat finish baking the cookies. After letting them cool and set, you're left with a deliciously soft, yummy treat.

text:
Alright, these cookies have never failed to impress. I've been making them for years now - but I'm allergic to nuts and thus enforce my choice on everyone around me (when it comes to my cooking) and happily leave them out of recipes. I substituted the nut amount with 1/2 cup more choc chips and 1/2 cup more oatmeal. This is one recipe I didn't use nut substitutes eg cornflakes, puffed rice etc. The cookies have always turned out great and have been a hit at potlucks, parties and at home. At 12 - 14 minutes of baking i end up with a crispy edged cookie with a chewy center. I added blue food colouring to a set and ended up with nice green cookies. Helped keep unwanted hands out of the cookie jar.

I am making the last few batches of these right now, and I had bf taste them.  He liked them--just thought they were undercooked.  I made the dough last night and refrigerated overnight, though--not bc I thought these cookies need that but bc I was too tired to bake the cookies last night!  They are easy and he liked them. Just before baking, I thought that my dough was still a bit too wet, so I added another 1/4th cup of oats just to be safe. Note: these cookies really flatten out in the oven.  Cookies turned out wonderfully. My boyfriend and I ate the entire batched in less than 48 hours. So so good.

These were really good, with the following modifications:  Omitted the walnuts, increased flour to 1 3/4c, increased bs to 1 tsp.  decreased salt to 1/2tsp.  I used old fashioned rolled oats instead of quick, and used the smart balance 50/50 blend sticks.   Chilled the dough for 30 min.  Baked the 1st batch at 325, for 20 min, the second batch at 350 for 12 min.  Neither batch really flattened out, but the second batch was definitely "puffier".  Will make again, and will add 1/2 c more choc chips.

text:
I am giving this rating based on the recipe, not based on altering the recipe after reading a hundred reviews.  These cookies tasted good, but I needed to add a few minutes to the baking time.  I let the cookies on the pan for five or more minutes to cool, but these things still fell apart and we will be eating the crumbs with spoons. The only thing I did differently was omit the nuts (I have a one year old and there are nut allergies in the family) and only use 1/2 tsp salt - and I don't believe those changes caused the cookies to fall apart on me or the baking time to be wrong.  I think I will be trying some of the other highly rated chocolate chip cookie recipes on this site before using this one again.

text:
I absolutely love this recipe with the modifications suggested by ( Fervent Frugal Foodie ) I also used large flaked oats (not the instant kind!) and MINI semi sweet choco chips and added 2 or more large tblspoons of peanut butter to creamed mixture(just because i love a hint of peanut in everything). These baked at 335 for 12 minutes were unbelievabley good. They are chewy and extremely sweet so I would suggest if you don't like sweet cookies to leave out half a cup of sugar - be it brown or white.  I didn't add any salt either because of the peanut butter and butter i used was salted.  I tried making these cookies right a way and with dough that sat in the fridge and i couldnt tell a difference either way.  I also made my cookies farely large and squished them down a bit after they came out of the oven which for me worked fine! My 2 year old LOVES these oaty cookies.  I am going to try making them next time with 1/2 apple sauce and 1/2butter and minus a 1/2c of sugar :)!! THANKS FOR THESE .. This is my new MAIN oatmeal cookie!

text:
These cookies get 5 stars from the whole family. I, like many others have made a few modifications. 4 modifications actually. The first is I use Crisco Butter flavored shortening in the same measurement. The second is I use President's Choice Chocolate chips. They don't have any dairy in them so my son have them. (Milk allergy) The third is I double the amount of chocolate chips. Yum! And lastly, the fourth thing is I bake them on a stoneware pan for 16 minutes at 325 degrees.  I also use a medium sized ice cream type scoop to make uniform cookies. I get 15 cookies per pan and 3 pans so 45 cookies per batch.

This is a fantastic recipe and I will keep it in my favorites! Thanks so much for sharing it!!

text:
I reduced the brown sugar to 3/4 cup, non-packed. I also used 1/2 cup of whole wheat flour + 3/4 cup all-purpose flour to increase the whole grains. I put the dough in the frig to chill for about an hour before baking--they turned out perfectly...not too flat and perfectly chewy. I would definitely use the old-fashioned oats for really chewy cookies (using instant oats would probably decrease the chewiness). These were yummy. Everyone calls them granola bar cookies b/c they're so oat-y. Yum!

I used about half butter, half apple butter, didn't use any white sugar at all, increased flour by 1/4 cup more, and oats by the same amount. I used full tsp of baking soda in total, and half choc. chips and half skor caramel bits. Chilled the dough for 30 mins, and baked at 335 for 12 mins as suggested by one reviewer. Turned out pretty good, but not chewy....more soft. Maybe I made them too big, or should have just gone with 1/2 tsp of baking soda next time. Still pretty good.

text:
If you like oatmeal, you'll love this cookie! As other users suggested I added 1/2 cup flour and 1/2 tsp baking soda. I didn't, however, omit the salt because I used unsalted butter. If using salted butter, it is best to decrease or omit salt altogether. I halved the batch and made one with white chocolate chips and cranberries, and the other with milk chocolate chips and walnuts. Both were equally great! No need to refrigerate dough, and baked exactly per recipe instructions. Cookie came out perfectly puffy, and not flat as others suggested.

text:
This is my fail-safe oatmeal cookie recipe.  I learned quickly to make them when I'm home alone, or they're gone before the last tray even has a chance to cool x)
  
Due to some allergies in my family I omit the nuts, and double the chocolate chips.
Other than that the only change I make is the addition of a sprinkle of cinnamon to the batter.  They don't -need- it, I just really like the extra flavour.
I live in a dry climate, and am very pleased that they don't dry out like crazy as so many other cookie recipes do.

Great recipe.  I have made it hundreds of times by now I'm sure.  Every time we're in charge of desert for potluck functions I make a large batch and never have any to bring home by the end of the night.

this is a great recipe but i knocked off a star because i definitely wouldn't call them chewy.  they are a nice soft/crumbly texture - not crisp or chewy.  to ease my guilt, i cut the sugars exactly in half and replaced 1/4c flour with 1/4c flaxmeal.  i also cut the chips in half.  my family didn't even notice and loved the cookies!  they taste just as good and become a healthy snack instead of a guilty conscience.
i used a tablespoon measure to scoop the dough and then flattened them out (they don't do this on their own).  it made 2inch diameter cookies - 50 cookies total.

text:
These are very good cookies. I'm not over the moon about them, but I really like them. I used used 1/2 whole wheat flour and 1/2 all purpose. I also increased the oats to 3 1/2 c. and decreased the salt to 1/2 tsp. as some reviewers suggested. I doubled the chocolate chips because I omitted the walnuts.  I also added 1/2 tsp. of cinnamon. I didn't have any trouble with them spreading.  In fact, next time I make them, I will probably flatten them a bit on the cookie sheet before I put them in the oven. These are VERY rich cookies (2 sticks of butter!!!). I think the next time I make them I will substitute a half cup of the butter for 1/2c. of applesauce. I might also cut back on the sugar a bit too. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I found this recipe after my husband's request to make a chocolate chip cookie like "Dad's Chewy Chocolate Chip" store brand.  This cookie came as close as possible.  
I did change a could of things. I did as previous mentioned with regards to the flour, baking soda and salt adjustments.  In addition, I added baking powder (equalling to the same amount of baking soda, ie:  1 tsp powder for 1 tsp soda).  Living at a higher elevation, this allowed my cooking to finish flat.  
Since I didn't have walnuts, I began using coconut instead.  The cookies came out perfect each time.  He loves them and I've already have made 12 doz since the beginning of the year for him.  And secretly, I love them too!  This is an excellent recipe for anyone who wants a soft good tasting chocolate chip cookie.

text:
I just finished making a batch of these cookies and they turned out beautifully. They stayed almost the same shape after baking as they did raw on the cookie sheet. For those having problems with flat cookies, make sure you do not use melted butter or a butter substitute that contains water as this will make your cookies spread. In trying to make a healthier cookie I used 1/2c crunchy unsalted peanut butter and substituted 3/4c unbleached flour and 3/4c oat flour (you can find this in the organic section of your store)for the regular white flour. I omitted the white sugar and used all brown. This made a not too sweet cookie. Very good.

text:
I just finished baking a batch of these cookies.  I made slight variations to the recipe: reduced the butter slightly and substituted 1 1/2 cup quick cook oats and 1 1/2 cup old fashioned oats instead of the 3 cups of quick cook oats and I added a touch of cinnamon.  I baked the cookies for 12 minutes and removed them at that time, even though they appeared to be underdone.  To my surprise, they were completely cooked.  I did not notice the spreading problem that others mentioned, but that is probably because I reduced the butter to 3/4 cup instead of 1 cup.  Overall, not a bad cookie.  I would reduce the salt in the next go around - these are a little on the salty side.  I'm sure I will not have any problem getting rid of them - my neighbors will love them :)  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Keeping it real here, the texture and depth of these cookies is outstanding. I used half butter, half margarine, added an extra 1/4 cup of flour and 1/2 tsp of baking soda and refrigerated my dough and the texture was perfect! I did add extra milk chocolate chips. I'd recommend anyone do this.  I only had 1/2 cup of pecans, and that was plenty. For my last 2 batches, I added raisins and cinnamon, and those turned out the best. I may make these again, but they are definitely not my all-time favorite cookies. Had better, had worse.

text:
After reading the 600+ rave reviews of this recipe, I decided to try it out with my five year old son, who wanted to make our usual peanut butter-chocolate chip cookies. I should have given in to his request. 

These cookies are not bad, but they don't live up to whatever quality everyone else touted. They are ever so slightly salty (and I halved the salt as recommended with salted butter). They are not terribly chewy, and are simply not as satisfying as you would expect a chocolate chip cookie to be. 

I'm going to stick to my old stand-by peanut butter-chocolate chip cookies and keep raisins in my oatmeals. Then everyone will be happy.

These cookies are SUPERB! These are my boyfriend's favourite cookies and my entire family LOVES them! I've made them a number of different times using milk choc chips and milk choc chips and chopped almonds. Some variations I always make each time - always use egg whites intead of whole eggs, I triple the amount of vanilla, add about 1/8-1/4 more oats, reduce the white sugar by about 1/8 of a cup and I flatten the cookies with my fingers a bit before baking since they don't tend to spread.
They are fantastic each and every time, guaranteed!

text:
This recipe is very good, but of course I had to add my own personal touches.

Firstly, I have read some reviews of the cookies coming out flat.  I think this is caused by the 325 oven, not the ingredients.  My first batch came out flat at 325, so I upped the temp to 350 and they came out perfectly.  Baking at 325 melts the butter before the cookies set and begin to brown and that's what flattens them out.

The only other tweaks I made was ditching the walnuts and doubling the chocolate chunks to 2 cups (a whole bag of chips).  I also add a teaspoon of cinnamon when adding the vanilla.  I love the combo of cinnamon and chocolate, and with the oats it really makes for a delicious, soul warming cookie.

Mmmmmm.  Soft and chewy and just plain delicious!  Wonderful flavor, texture...all!!  EDIT:  Tried making these again with some of the tips from the reviews (specifically using 1 3/4 cups flour, 1 teaspoon baking soda and only 1/2 teaspoon salt...and chilling them for 15 minutes before baking).  I thought they tasted the same, but I didn't really feel like there was a difference in the rising so so many reviewer said.  They were still relatively thin cookies, but equally delicious.  I did cook them on parchment paper, which really helps keep them soft/chewy.  They were even as delicious day 2 and still pretty good/soft (although not AS good) day 3, which is a huge plus for me!

region:

country:

text:
These cookies were delicious!!! When I scribbled down the recipe, I missed the baking soda in it, and figured that the recipe had called for 1 teaspoon of it, so that's what I added.  Also, I started with 1/2 teaspoon salt, then increased it to 3/4 teaspoon (just for personal preferences).  I spilled some extra vanilla in the dough, so it probably ended up being closer to 1 tablespoon (3 teaspoons) instead of 2 teaspoons. I was out of quick-cooking oats, so I used old-fashioned rolled oats, 3 cups, and it turned out fine.  For the people who are mentioning the batter being really runny, it could be the butter you are using.  In general, I always use real butter in my cookies, which I think makes a big difference.  If you use margarine, though, experts I have read say that you should always look for a margarine with 70% fat in it to bake with, otherwise your cookies will be watery and runny.  Tub margarines are especially prone to this problem, since most of them have less fat than stick margarines. Overall, I found the cookies to be chewy on the inside, crisp around the edges and overall good tasting.  I do sometimes add some cinnamon or some cloves to my oatmeal chocolate chip cookies, but these really did not need them, in my opinion, especially with the extra vanilla I accidentally added.

text:
These cookies were MUCH better the next day than they were right out of the oven.  In the future, I will probably substitute shortening for the butter and add a bit more flour to thicken up the dough.  I found the just-baked cookies to be very gooey, so much so that they didn't even hold a good cookie shape on the pan and turned into little puddles of cookies instead.  However, and they're thoroughly cooled they're quite tasty.
